bug.short_desc: [IDE] Enhance "Resource Exists" dialog

long_desc.thetext:
If I copy a file into a directory already containing a file with the same name, the "Resource Exists" dialog appears, for which I have two enhancements in mind:
First, I'd like to see the size of the two files.
Second, I think it would be nice to add a "Compare" button for text files: Clicking that button would open a dialog similar to the "Replace with/Local history", showing the difference between the two files.
Could maybe somebody point me to the classes where that Dialog is realized? I'll then try to provide a patch that at least fixes the file size thing...
See RenameResourceAction

bug.short_desc: [Web connector] Support queries that require login

long_desc.thetext:
For example querying a private phpBB or vBulletin forum is not possible because authentication is not implemented.
To support adding login implementation to templates, maybe the extension point could optionally include a reference to a class that implements a certain interface. I imagine that making this very generic is quite a task, but it would be good to support at least the typical login scenario that asks for username & password and uses cookies for state -- at least phpBB and vBulletin usually work this way.
I am willing to help with this, but I will be unavailable for the next 7 or 8 days. A working HttpClient cookie-based login implementation for phpBB and vBulletin can be found here: http://bbapi.tigris.org/source/browse/bbapi/trunk/ , in the org.tigris.bbapi.phpbb and org.tigris.bbapi.vbulletin plugins. vBulletin ( look in PHPBB.login(IBBCredentials) and the same method in the VBulletin class )

Doesn't entering the credentials via the web browser work for the duration of the Eclipse session? That has been my experience using Bugzilla and Jira in the web mode.
Note that we're starting to upt some support for HttpClient connections in mylar.internal.tasks.core.WebClientUtil

(In reply to comment #1) > Doesn't entering the credentials via the web browser work for the duration of > the Eclipse session? That has been my experience using Bugzilla and Jira in > the web mode.
Yes, but those are not used when fetching query results.

(In reply to comment #2) > (In reply to comment #1) > > Doesn't entering the credentials via the web browser work for the duration of > > the Eclipse session? That has been my experience using Bugzilla and Jira in > > the web mode. > > Yes, but those are not used when fetching query results. >
entering credentials for sourceforge does not work for me, linux firefox 1.5. but that might be a linux browser problem, as it sometimes causes Eclipse to crash!

(In reply to comment #3) > entering credentials for sourceforge does not work for me, linux firefox 1.5. > but that might be a linux browser problem, as it sometimes causes Eclipse to > crash!
Can you please clarify where you entering credentials?
User and password from repository dialog are not used right now, but Mylar does not allow to remove these fields from there for repository connector.
However, browser could ask for credentials when entering some pages and is completely in the browser. Though as far as I recall, SF is using form-based auth, which is not needed to run queries, only when adding or editing issues.

Ok, I finally have actual need for this and I'm thinking it could be done like this: allow to specify via UI 1) a login URL 2) OPTIONAL: whether it should be a GET or POST request (just doing a POST is probably enough for all cases in reality) 3) specify all GET/POST parameters as name/value pairs (the values could use string replace to replace %username% and %password% or something like that) 4) OPTIONAL: specify separately which parameter name is used for username and password
Then just remember the cookies.
I could use this to experiment using Mylar with ChangeLogic manually for about two weeks with another developer. The information we gather this way should be shared with the ChangeLogic developers and hopefully we will help them decide to create a ChangeLogic integration :)
Adding Karel Kravik to cc. -- Karel, is the above list enough to login to ChangeLogic? Or maybe logging in with an activation key is possible? (explanation: after the login request, another request would be made to query the task list and parse it with regular expressions).

Eugene: since this bug belongs to you please request for me to apply any patch that you would like applied and I will review.

The previous patch didn't initialize the new fields in the wizard page if you were editing an existing query.

Fixed externalization, previously the value of Login URL was externalized instead of Login Page URL's value.

(In reply to comment #10) > Eugene: since this bug belongs to you please request for me to apply any patch > that you would like applied and I will review.
Will look at it next week.
I'm thinking that putting the password in the URL is a bad security blooper, so the POST parameters mentioned in comment #5 really should be added to this model.

Created an attachment (id=52838) This patch adds template support
This patch adds the possibility to specifiy the login url and login token regexp in the templates. But I didn't add the "Login page url" as a template attribute, but used the Repository URL to fill that field.
Erkki, why do you have login parameters at the query level? Shouldn't all these params be in the repository settings?
Hmm, now that I think of it, you are right. Should be at the repo level. I think my logic was that nothing besides the query requires that kind of login.

Eugene, I really like the new UI for the web repositories. How do you think the login parameters could be added to that?
If just replacing the username/password in the URL, that would be easier, but I don't think it should be done like that -- it was just a temporary solution for me.
So another parameter table is probably necessary for a POST login. I suggest to add
option 1) to the hidden advanced section:
Login token pattern (that would be read from the main repository page, but maybe in some rare cases where both public and privileged access is possible there is a need to read that token from a different page... that case should probably not dealt with prematurely though, as I did in the original patch) Login URL A table with POST parameters for the login.
option 2) add the same items in a new section "Login configuration" below the "Advanced configuration" that is also hidden by default
option 3) add a button to open a new dialog with the login options.
I personally like option #2 the most.

Or actually, as it seems the ParametersEditor would work better on a different page, why not have an
"Anonymous Access" checkbox checked by default as in the Bugzilla and Trac repository settings and in case it is unchecked, make the Next button go to a new advanced login settings page? Hmm... on the other hand, the advanced page should not be shown at all in the most common cases. I think in that case both "Next" and "Finish" could be visible and "Next" would go to the advanced login configuration page while Finish would finish immediately.

Created an attachment (id=54126) Bugfixes and new ChangeLogic templates to the previous patch
1) several bugs fixed that the previous patch created 2) there are now 2 ChangeLogic templates: 2a) anonymous (default server changelogic.araneaframework.org) -- this allows to view public tasks anonymously. The query pattern is not perfect -- for some tasks the status is retrieved instead of the description 2b) with POST login (default server also changelogic.araneaframework.org -- it allows users to sign up) -- this worked for me with 3 different changelogic instances.
Created an attachment (id=54128) Updated screensot of the Login Configuration UI

This looks great Erkki. I think that it just needs a bit of UI simplification and we can apply the patch. Where is the "Login Tken Pattern" coming from? Should it be part of the template? Eugene, could you take a look and verify it?
1) Remove the folding sections, because they add UI complexity, and if a user is looking at this they should see it all. Replace them with check boxes that cause the items below them to enable. As an example take a look at the Proxy Settings section of the Bugzilla repository properties page, just checked into CVS a moment ago. 2) Put URL on the same line as Method to save a line, with Method going first. 3) "Advanced Configuration" -> "Template Configuration (Advanced)" 4) "Login Configuration (Expert)" -> "Login Configuration (Advanced)" 5) To get rid of the white call setBackground on the composite with the container's background.

(In reply to comment #28) > Should it be part of the template? Eugene, could you take a look and verify it?
Yes, it is definitely should be coming from template.
I haven't look at the code yet, but have few comments in regards to UI and some implementation details.
First of all this folding idea (even for original advanced section) is becoming a real mess. The size of expanded UI is too large to sit under the fold. I think it all should be moved to the separate page (or a popup edit dialog in worst case).
Also, we don't need two property tables. There should be only one!
> ...As an example take a look at the Proxy > Settings section of the Bugzilla repository properties page, just checked into > CVS a moment ago.
Hmm. Why it only appear for Bugzilla and not for other connectors?
It is also very disappointing that you used folded sections instead of multiple pages. :-(
> 2) Put URL on the same line as Method to save a line, with Method going first. > 3) "Advanced Configuration" -> "Template Configuration (Advanced)" > 4) "Login Configuration (Expert)" -> "Login Configuration (Advanced)"
Actually, I believe there should be just one "advanced" section. There is no point to separate this stuff. For example, login token can be used in other urls. So, they are quite related.
> 5) To get rid of the white call setBackground on the composite with the > container's background.
That one I actually left white intentionally, to separate from the other UI.
Either way, I'd like to take my own pass to the UI. Ie remove all the borders and align the widgets properly

(In reply to comment #29) > Yes, it is definitely should be coming from template. Yes, and an example is present in the ChangeLogic templates also included in this patch.
> a real mess. The size of expanded UI is too large to sit under the fold. I > think it all should be moved to the separate page (or a popup edit dialog in > worst case).
I agree that a separate page would be good. But should it be accessible by the "Next" button or in some other way?
> Also, we don't need two property tables. There should be only one!
Do you mean that there should be only one table where you enter properties (1) or that there should be only one implementation of a table where you enter key/value pairs (2).
If it is 1) then I disagree -- the login request parameters should be hidden by default unlike the template parameters. If it's 2) then I agree -- the whole restui package could probably be replaced with something better, I did it the way it is because it was easy to develop a prototype that way in Visual Editor. Also, I think to enter the parameters directly in the table is better than a pop-up dialog (but maybe harder to do validation? -- haven't tried that in a table yet).
> > 2) Put URL on the same line as Method to save a line, with Method going first.
Moving the method and URL to one line sounds good.
> Either way, I'd like to take my own pass to the UI. Ie remove all the borders > and align the widgets properly
Ok.

(In reply to comment #30) > I agree that a separate page would be good. But should it be accessible by the > "Next" button or in some other way?
Technically you not suppose to have "Next" buttons on properties dialogs. Those buttons are used for wizards. See Team/CVS repository properties.
> > Also, we don't need two property tables. There should be only one! > > Do you mean that there should be only one table where you enter properties (1) > or that there should be only one implementation of a table where you enter > key/value pairs (2). > > If it is 1) then I disagree -- the login request parameters should be hidden by > default unlike the template parameters.
You don't have anything to hide. More over, there is no point to map username to just ${userId} variable, so as other remappings you have used.
Regardless, two property tables on the same dialog are really confusing and really make no sense.

(In reply to comment #31) > Technically you not suppose to have "Next" buttons on properties dialogs. Those > buttons are used for wizards. See Team/CVS repository properties.
Ok, I see what you mean.
> > If it is 1) then I disagree -- the login request parameters should be hidden by > > default unlike the template parameters. > > You don't have anything to hide. More over, there is no point to map username > to just ${userId} variable, so as other remappings you have used.
> Regardless, two property tables on the same dialog are really confusing and > really make no sense.
But I don't really see how you could present any differently the info that needs to be sent with the POST login request. You could call them repository parameters, but they aren't -- they won't be used as variables, they are used only in that login HTTP request and nowhere else. And you can't send the other parameters with the login request, so to put them in one table, you'd have to somehow separate them with a prefix or add another column where you select which kind of parameter it is.
In ChangeLogic's case, I could actually use a GET method and put the whole POST Parameters table in the query, but that would be a more insecure way to send them.
The mapping for ${userId} etc. is very much necessary if you want to use the standard repository username/password parameters to send with the login request and not enter them twice.
All this works exactly the same way as what you did with introducing the parameters/variables -- you enter somewhat human-readable parameters in one table and the other more advanced fields make use of those variables.

(In reply to comment #32) > But I don't really see how you could present any differently the info that > needs to be sent with the POST login request.
Why exactly you need to present them differently? Can't you just put them into the post url?
> You could call them repository > parameters, but they aren't -- they won't be used as variables, they are used > only in that login HTTP request and nowhere else. And you can't send the other > parameters with the login request, so to put them in one table, you'd have to > somehow separate them with a prefix or add another column where you select > which kind of parameter it is.
Parameters only sent somewhere if they are actually used in the urls. I see what you meant them for now, but if passing those in the url works for you, it would make UI less cluttered, especially with currently used folding...
Or even better, parse that login url and convert params from the url into post parameters. This way it is even easier to store in templates.
> In ChangeLogic's case, I could actually use a GET method and put the whole POST > Parameters table in the query, but that would be a more insecure way to send > them.
Don't be silly. There is nothing secure about post. :-) If you really care about security, use https.
> The mapping for ${userId} etc. is very much necessary if you want to use the > standard repository username/password parameters to send with the login request > and not enter them twice.
I know. That is why I added ${userId} variable in first place.

Yes, POST is not secure by itself, but are you sure that in HTTPS there is no difference between how the body of a request and the URL are treated? POST parameters are sent in the request body, not in the URL. Hmm... maybe this difference between URL / body is a misconception I have... I'm forgetting that this is not used in a browser where a URL is more insecure because it's usually always visible. But what about caching, proxies etc. Do they not make a difference between POST/GET (or URL and body). I must admit that I'm no expert on this and I'm not 100% sure on any of it.
Parsing the URL into post parameters is one possibility, but there might be some cases that expect some parameters in the URL and some as POST parameters (If I'm not mistaken, phpBB or vBulletin did that somewhere).

Actually, I checked phpBB & vBulletin login impl. in BBAPI and neither require any URL parameters besides POST parameters. The probability of some application requiring that should be quite low. So I think parsing the URL into post parameters would be ok and the table could be dropped.
Great. Parsing login url it is. :-)

Created an attachment (id=54277) Updated patch with simplified UI
1) The login request now fits on one line. Maybe the 'restui' package should be removed now and the code embedded in the settings page compilation unit? 2) no more special parameters -- as discussed, for POST method the URL query is now parsed into the POST method parameters. The parsing is not perfect, though. For example, the parameters are evaluated before the URL parsing so if the password/username contains &, it will be seen as separator. Not entirely sure yet how it's best to keep this URL parsing simple while allowing special characters. 3) synchronized with latest CVS changes -- mostly it was that there seemed to be some differently formatted code in CVS
Note: since for the parameter evaluation, the fetchResource method now needs the repository as a parameter, maybe some other parameters from the method could be dropped.

I can't apply patch because of conflicts in WebQueryWizardPage and WebRepositoryConnector classes. Are you sure you have latest code?
PS: when substituting parameters we need to use http encoder. There is one in Mylar core classes...

In WebRepositoryConnector: 1) the fetchResource() now doesn't take as many parameters, as the TaskRepository is given as a parameter. 2) did an extract method refactoring: refreshIfNeeded()

FYI. With this patch applied I got an NPE for existing query:
java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.mylar.internal.tasks.web.WebRepositoryConnector.evaluateParams(WebRepositoryConnector.java:432) at org.eclipse.mylar.internal.tasks.web.WebRepositoryConnector.evaluateParams(WebRepositoryConnector.java:415) at org.eclipse.mylar.internal.tasks.web.WebRepositoryConnector.performQuery(WebRepositoryConnector.java:177) at org.eclipse.mylar.tasks.ui.SynchronizeQueryJob.run(SynchronizeQueryJob.java:74) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)

Created an attachment (id=54299) Redesigned UI layout
This is my take on this UI.
Damn it. It is getting more obscured then I initially thought. I now wonder if this ChangeLogic is the only issue tracker that require this token thing...

I think it would really be better on a separate properties page and in Groups. But then the whole properties dialog should be redesigned in every Mylar connector, I think? Currently it's designed like a Wizard, but functions more like those CVS/SVN properties pages, like you mentioned somewhere above. I personally think doing this would be good, but probably too much work for you guys right now?

Yes, redesigning the Repository Properties page to one of the other options (tabbed, or multi-page properties) can not happen for 1.0. There are tricky problems such as having the "Validate Settings" button in a sensible place where you can see all the relevant settings. Also, the folding approach provides a good forcing function for making the UI dense, as Eugene seems to have done a very good job of in his last iteration.
Eugene: Let me know when you guys have the patch in a state where you want me to apply it.
Also, is ChangeLogic really the only tracker that this will support? That's not great, bug I guess it's OK if we're reasonably confident that this mechanism could be useful for other web based repositories that we will support down the road.

(In reply to comment #44) > Eugene: Let me know when you guys have the patch in a state where you want me > to apply it.
Ok then, I'll finish UI changes I started and will cleanup Erkki's code (ie remove printStackTrace() and some other stuff).
> Also, is ChangeLogic really the only tracker that this will support? That's not > great, bug I guess it's OK if we're reasonably confident that this mechanism > could be useful for other web based repositories that we will support down the > road.
Sorry, I meant that that logging in should work on others repositories. Though I yet have to check how Erkki implemented passing session between requests. What is specific to ChangeLogic is that login token id and hence an extra request to the server to fetch it. As I said, I don't recall anyone else doing something like that, but I can be wrong.

Session is currently not persisted between requests (would this be useful? personally I didn't consider that to be important). To persist the session, the HttpClient or it's cookie state should be cached. I guess there is even some kind of possibility of sharing the session with the internal browser?
I have seen this token usage in other web applications, but I'm not sure if any issue repositories use that. vBulletin or phpBB I think uses something similar during posting messages, but as I remember it isn't mandatory.

Created an attachment (id=54456) Reworked patch with login support and new templates
Here we are. I am sorry to say that there is very little code left from the original patch because I rewrote most of the resource fetching code.
Since there is no public CodeLogic repo with auth, I've used OTRS as a driver for this. Mik, can you please review and apply this patch. WebRepositoryConnectorTest may flicker on OTRS repository, because tasks are up and down.
So, this patch adds 3 new templates: OTRS, CodeLogic and CodeBeamer.
Erkki, I used one template for both repositories. Please check if it work for you once Mik will apply this patch. Then, if you need additional fixes, please make sure that WebRepositoryConnectorTest is working. Thanks.
Created an attachment (id=54457) mylar/context/zip

Folks, if this patch (finally) gets applied on the next hours, is it possible to release a dev-build to try this feature?
I have not external CVS access here, but I'd like to experiment with it.
Also, is it complicated to add Mantis login support out of the box too, Eugene?

Note that we messed up the Task Repositories page for you some and will clean that up today. I think for now we'll make the Character encoding fold since most people don't need to see that.
I was just going to make encoding a single dorp down, or checkbox (Default Encoding) and dropdown...

> Here we are. I am sorry to say that there is very little code left from the > original patch because I rewrote most of the resource fetching code.
I don't mind :)
>Erkki, I used one template for both repositories. Please check if it work for >you once Mik will apply this patch. Then, if you need additional fixes, please >make sure that WebRepositoryConnectorTest is working. Thanks.
It doesn't work for me at the moment (with the private repo), I will take a look at it (and the new code) later when I get home.

Eugene: the single drop down sounds good, and if you end up doing this just try to put "Default (UTF-8)" as the first entry because that list is soooo huge and if someone clicks this accidentally they will never find the default again. It's OK if it's duplicated and shows up as (UTF-8) later.

(In reply to comment #53) > It doesn't work for me at the moment (with the private repo), I will take a > look at it (and the new code) later when I get home.
Note that there is a bug with POST method authentication and redirect handling in the applied patch. See bug#165852.

(In reply to comment #47) > Erkki, I used one template for both repositories. Please check if it work for you once Mik will apply this patch. Then, if you need additional fixes, please make sure that WebRepositoryConnectorTest is working. Thanks.
Merging the patterns doesn't work well because the private task list page differs from the public one. Perhaps the private template should not be part of Mylar (unless you accept having two Changelogic templates), and I could contribute it as a patch or separate jarred plugin attached to the Changelogic enh. request (bug 159346)?

Sorry, my bad, it seems you succesfully managed to make the pattern support both pages, but what was causing me trouble was the problem mentioned by Willian.
Also, another thing: not only HTTP 302 should indicate that the new URL be read from the Location header, but also: 301,302,303,307 Also, with 300, "user agents MAY use the Location field value for automatic redirection" This is for HTTP 1.1, don't know about 1.0
I specifically need it to work with 301, because my server redirects the login page from something like cvs.lan/changelogic to cvs.lan/changelogic/ with "301 Moved Permanently"

(In reply to comment #58) > But actually, why do this manually and set method.setFollowRedirects(false), > when this could be done by HttpClient instead? It looks like this is how > HttpClient does it internally:

bug.short_desc: Problem charting a sub-set of a data set using the expression builder.

long_desc.thetext:
I posted on the BIRT news group first and was asked to file a report. My newsgroup post is here: http://www.eclipse.org/newsportal/article.php?id=11895&group=eclipse.birt#11895
I'm trying to chart a dataset and a subset on a scatter graph. For the subset i'm using the expression builder with the line of code below. if ((row["VALUE"]) > 10) row["VALUE"];
I wish to show the origional dataset allong with a subset of it where the values are greater than 10. When i preview the chart i'm getting the error below. Can anyone help? Thanks

bug.short_desc: [Contributions] Enablement not updated when menu shown, only when selection changes

long_desc.thetext: This is another example where computing enablement on-demand (rather than requiring selection and other kinds of listeners to be hooked for any state that can affect enablement) would be simpler. That's effectively what this workaround achieves, but unfortunately it requires an internal reference to PluginAction.
Note to self: corresponding Jazz bug is #7454.
In 3.2, it appears this is only an issue for viewer contributions. Object contributions are added each time the menu is shown, and their selection is updated.
See also bug 48326.
Assigning to component owner PW

bug.short_desc: Single word selection not possible for HTML attributes in JSP editor

long_desc.thetext: System { JDK1.5.0. eclipse.buildId=I20060602-1317 } Problem { I typed this into the JSP editor: src="<%=MrBean.ContextUri%>/images/<%=color%>TopLeft.gif" width="8" I double-clicked on the word [color], only the text [color] is selected as expected. However, if I double-clicked on [images], the whole string [MrBean.ContextUri%>/images/<%=color%>TopLeft.gif] is selected. I typed: src="/images/color/value" I double-clicked on the word [color], only the text [color] is selected as expected. I typed: I double-clicked on the word [color], the whole string [/images/color/value] is selected, which is unexpected. } Question { Is this a feature or a bug? I prefer to view this as bug. Perhaps, there is an eclipse setting for double-click selects [word | quoted phrase]. If there is, I can't locate that setting. Preferably, double-click selects word and triple-click selects quoted phrase. }

I typed in another string in the JSP: <td width="100%" color >
I decided it should be: <td width="100%" class="<%= color" >
The editor nosily gave me: <td width="100%" class="<%= %>color" >
So now I have to move [color] into the [<%= %>] enclosure. I double-clicked color hoping to move [color] so that the string becomes: <td width="100%" class="<%=color %>">
I expected that only the word [color] would be selected. But no, the phrase [%>color] was selected.
Hrmphh ... I'm going back to netbeans!
Mi, the JSP editor is provided by Webtools

Part of what you are seeing is "features" (to select a word on first double click, to select a whole attribute value on next double click). [a second double click expands to whole tag, anohter cycles].
It sounds like a good request, though, that we beef this up in two ways. 1) we should be better aware of "word" boundries, and take those into account better. 2) we should be aware of what we call "nested regions" (that's the JSP inside the attribute value) and know to treat it as just a part of a whole.
Amy, can you look into these usability improvements?

bug.short_desc: [WorkbenchParts] Wizard launches multiple times

long_desc.thetext:
We had a file with extension .foo associated with our wizard. When we double click on it, the wizard launches. However it seems wizard launches three times because when we click on cancel button, it launches again. I tried the simple "Hello World" scenario and saw it printed three times. Here is the extension point we are using:
<extension point="org.eclipse.ui.editors"> <editor name="Test Launcher" extensions="foo" icon="icons/sample.gif" launcher="com.ibm.etools.iseries.test.editors.FooLauncher" id="com.ibm.etools.iseries.test.editors.FooLauncher"> </editor> </extension>

Created an attachment (id=46718) Simple plugin we created
This is simple plugin we created. After get plugin into IDE, create a file called test.foo in java or web project. Then double click on the file "test.foo", the console will show "launcher" three times.

I won't have time to look at this before 3.3M2 (which is in 2 weeks).
Sorry, PW

With Eric and Howards help we were able to track this down to a viewer provided by datatools. They have fixed the problem in their development stream.
PW

bug.short_desc: GMF build needs to migrate to unified Modeling Project build

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, we maintain our own build process/scripts for just GMF. Within the new Modeling project, a goal is to unify our build and reporting mechanisms across most (if not all) projects.
With this, GMF and the Modeling project should participate in the Europa Build Workshop http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php?title=Europa_Build_Workshop

As discussed with Nick at EclipseCon, we should read through this procedure and provide feedback given our preferences (structure, local builds, cruisecontrol usage, etc.) http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/EMFT_Procedures

A recent discussion with Nick regarding the state of the Modeling builder revealed a few issues we'd like to see resolved before moving:
- We need the ability to install and run the build on local machines, not just on Eclipse machines. Virtualization has been suggested (VMware) as a solution. - We need to minimize dependencies to simplify installation/invocation of builds. Ideally, we'd just need a basebuilder, project builder, CVS and Ant. -... additional feedback sent to Nick.
Setting target milestone to ---.

bug.short_desc: GMF should support project Orbit

long_desc.thetext: GMF's utilization of 3rd party libraries (namely, Batik) should be from the newly proposed Orbit project http://www.eclipse.org/proposals/orbit/
Note bug 171869 as a way to incorporate the fetching of orbit bundles into the build. However, as pointed out in bug 171955, it's still a better idea for Orbit to provide an update site (imo).
GMF starting from M7 is consuming Orbit bundles

bug.short_desc: Remove deprecations from plugin.xml

long_desc.thetext:
The plugin.xml for the org.eclipse.pde.ui plug-in has a few deprecations on it due to changes in the org.eclipse.ui.propertyPages extension point schema.
We should make them go away.

Created an attachment (id=46740) org.eclipse.pde.ui.patch
PDE will have none of this deprecated'ness

Created an attachment (id=46742) org.eclipse.pde.ui.patch
reposting for sanity, I don't get errors
patch applied. Thanks Chris.

bug.short_desc: Unable to change ANT HOME from RUN AS dialog

long_desc.thetext:
Using Eclipse 3.2.1 (also happens w/ 3.2.0)
1. right click an ANT build.xml file and select "Run As -> Ant Build ..." menu. 2. Select the classpath tab 3. select Ant Home My workspace was created by a previous Eclipse version. The version no longer exists on my system. The Ant Home library paths all point to the previous install. 4. click "Ant Home..." button 5. select the ant plugin location within the current 3.2.1 install 6. click "Apply"
7. nothing happens.
Avoidance: Modify ANT HOME from the Window -> Preferences -> Ant -> Runtime menu.
mg

This is a side effect of migrating the Ant classpath to a new format. The old Ant home is maintained incorrectly.
There are workarounds so no further work is planned.

bug.short_desc: [KeyBindings] keybinding not enabled even though actions appear enabled in menus

long_desc.thetext:
NOTE: Using latest 3.3 integration build (Build id: I20060718-0800), and a rework of the "java debugger evaluation actions" from latest patch in bug 128255.
The patch replaces the Java evaluation actions with a new "retargettable" action that performs evaluations using "evaluation adapters" from the active part. I find that I get into a state where the keybinding (eg. CTRL-SHIFT-I) does not work for "Inspect", but that all the menus (Window, Editor or View) show the action as enabled, and when I use the action from the menu it works.
Following is a trace of output from the workbench, along with "sysout's" showing the enablement calls to the underlying "action delegates". Note that I eventually press the "inspect command's" key-binding, but it's handler is not enabled.
To apply/use the debug patch, you need the following plug-ins from HEAD:
org.eclipse.debug.core org.eclipse.debug.ui org.eclipse.jdt.debug org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui
Steps to reproduce (approximate, as it just seems to take time to fail) * Debug to a breakpoint * Activate the associated editor * Select some text, and press CTRL-SHIFT-I for inspect * (usually works) * Dismiss the popup, place cursor at beginning of line in editor * Activate the Variables view * select a variable and its details text * activate the editor again, by clicking on its tab * select more text and try "CTRL-SHIFT-I" (Sometimes fails now)
------------------------------------------------------

My notes: This seems to be connected to part of the command framework that is disconnected.
The workbench window/selection/menu items are tied to IActions like ViewPluginAction or EditorPluginAction. These are having setEnabled(*) called on them.
The commands point to ActionDelegateHandlerProxy, which has an IAction of CommandLegacyActionWrapper. This is not properly tied into the workbench window IAction framework, and so the calls to setEnabled(*) are not being seen by the handler.
PW

Created an attachment (id=64633) action enabled state v02
Before a keybinding is executed it will call isEnabled(). This will give the IActionDelegate the opportunity to update its enabled state on the isEnabled() call.
PW

(In reply to comment #11) > Created an attachment (id=64633) [details] > action enabled state v02 >
This is perhaps not so good as a transition state. Some commands are executed with a specific context, and isEnabled() can only use the global context.
PW

Hi!
Why not calling refreshEnablement always in isEnabled? isEnabled is not called very often anyway. This is simple (but may have a negative impact on the performance).
Otherwise, a clean solution would be if the ActionDelegateHandlerProxy listened to selection changes. Currently, although ActionDelegateHandlerProxy is a selection listener, it is never notified with selection change events--as result the CommandLegacyActionWrapper is never updated.
Gerhard
P.S I was referring to ActionDelegateHandlerProxy.refreshEnablement and ActionDelegateHandlerProxy.isEnabled.

OK, in 3.3 it is part way there.
ActionDelegateHandlerProxy will ask the action delegate to update with the "current" selection before asking for its enabled state.
Handlers tied to a static context query the enabled state with that context.
PW

Hi Paul!
I was thinking that the static context might lead to the same issue in some cases.
Gerhard

Hi guys,
My issue is i want to enable or disable a workbench window action according to the current user role..
since i was not able to get the contribution element for disabling it at startup ,i used enablement(system Property) in action sets ,at startup i used to set the system propertys and the action got disabled,Note - all the actions had key bindings and worked fine..This was for 3.1...
when we tryed to migrate to 3.2 the key bindings stopped working,i debugged into eclipse and found that if u have a enablement u should have a selection..
can u guys suggest me any solution....
pls refer ActionDelegateHandlerProxy.isEnabled()..
Also the action set extention point discription doc explains a visibility element,but the same is not visible in PDE,i checked the exsd too and it has a attribute called visibility...
In code there are constants to retreave this visibility attribute and the attribute is not used any where..
PLS HELP
Thanks a lot

(In reply to comment #17) > Hi guys, > > when we tryed to migrate to 3.2 the key bindings stopped working,i debugged > into eclipse and found that if u have a enablement u should have a selection.. > > can u guys suggest me any solution.... > > pls refer ActionDelegateHandlerProxy.isEnabled()..
This particular part of the legacy disconnect problem was fixed in 3.3.
ActionDelegateHandlerProxy calls selectionChanged(*) on the IActionDelegate in isEnabled() before returning the enabled state.
PW

(In reply to comment #18) > (In reply to comment #17) > > Hi guys, > > > > when we tryed to migrate to 3.2 the key bindings stopped working,i debugged > > into eclipse and found that if u have a enablement u should have a selection.. > > > > can u guys suggest me any solution.... > > > > pls refer ActionDelegateHandlerProxy.isEnabled().. > This particular part of the legacy disconnect problem was fixed in 3.3. > ActionDelegateHandlerProxy calls selectionChanged(*) on the IActionDelegate in > isEnabled() before returning the enabled state. > PW

bug.short_desc: Specify an iFrame as a target for a drill through report

long_desc.thetext:
Right now the only 2 choices for the target of a drill through report are: new window or same window. I would like to be able to specify an iframe as the target. The use case is as follows:
In a report design I have a text item in which I specify HTML for the iframe. In this iframe I want to display the "child report". The reason is it is inconvenient to have multiple windows in my application.
I need an additional option associated with the target. This option would let me select from the following: 1) display target report with web viewer 2) display target in plain HTML 3) display target report in PDF. Right now I don't have this choice. If the parent report is displayed in the web viewer then all the target reports also get the web viewer. This is restrictive.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 146515 ***

bug.short_desc: [hotbug] OverwriteFilesEnabled=true does not have any effect in ant tasks

long_desc.thetext:
During Web service (or client) generation, some existing files need to be modified, one example would be web.xml inserting service-ref information.
Although we have "OverwriteFilesEnabled=true" in the properties file, this setting does not seem to take any effect at all. The Ant task completes successfully but web.xml does not get updated at all. The workaround is to enable the "Overwrite files without warning" preference under Web service. This probably would not be too convenient for user running the ant tasks on the command line.
Is this something that can be addressed in WTP 1.5.1?

Affiliation: IBM
Release you want this bug to be fixed in: WTP 1.5.1
Justification: This would fail Web serivce client generation and multiple Web service/client generation using the Web service Ant tasks.
Created an attachment (id=46830) Patch for org.eclipse.wst.command.env plugin
This patch has been reviewed and committed.
Released to HEAD and R1_5_maintenance as v200607270039. This will be in the 07/28 WTP 1.5.1 M-build.
verified in WTP 1.5.1
Closed.

bug.short_desc: random crashing, occurs in 3.2 and 3.1

long_desc.thetext:
I installed eclipse 3.1 in february, worked fine for several months, then suddenly started crashing randomly with increasing frequency until it became unusable. Tried to reinstall 3.1, was able to run for a few days before it began crashing again with the same pattern. Also tried different java versions, taking pains to be sure no other java version was use, and removed the only extra plugin we were using (Checkclipse). I also know that my PC was configured for automatic updates.
I decided to try 3.2, so I installed it, it ran ok for about four days, then started to crash randomly as 3.1 had done, with the same increasing frequency. Now it is crashing anywhere from 0 to 5 times an hour, and it often takes 2 or 3 restarts before I can begin work again.
When I say random crashing I mean that it crashes when rebuilding the workspace, when editing, and when manipulating the menus. Sometimes it crashes just after the splash screen appears, and I have to kill the process. It is also crashing when I am working in another application, and eclipse is seemingly idle. Several times I have left the computer, come back, and found that Eclipse has crashed. Many times the computer panics and shuts down.
I am surrounded by coworkers with the same machine and similar environment who have no trouble running their Eclipse of various versions, can find nothing out of place with my eclipse installation or project setup, I am using the same command line arguments they were. I tried altering a number of options (-clean vs no -clean, memory, jvm, etc) with no observable change in behaviour (still crashes).
I thought that there may have been a problem with 3.1.0 and a windows update, but at least one of my coworkers runs 3.1.0 with her automatic windows updates enabled.
I don't have any chronic PC problems with other applications. I am currently running 3.2 and Java 1.5.0.7, and haved tried 3.2 with 1.5.0.6, 1.4.2.12, 1.4.2.5. I have also tried 3.1 with 1.5.0.6 and 1.4.2.5. No combination seems to cause a working behaviour.
A quick browse through my growing collection of hs_err_pidXXXX.log files shows seemingly random problems on a variety of threads.
Please let me know what I can do further to assist you. I like Eclipse very much and am anxious to use it soon without wondering when it will crash next.
Please let me know if there is a solution to this.

Could you attach a couple of those error log files? It sounds to me something like a bad sector in your RAM... perhaps other applications aren't memory-intensive enough to run into it. The fact that the exact same software setup isn't failing on other PCs suggests a local problem.
Closing. Requested details not provided.

bug.short_desc: [API] Cannot Launch The New Plug-in Project Wizard Programmatically Through Public API

long_desc.thetext:
I'd like to have the new plug-in project wizard show up in another category. The wizard class, NewPluginProjectWizard, is internal. I can do what I want, but I have to refer to an internal class to do so.
There are a couple other items on my would be nice list. I'd like to be able to programmatically create a plug-in project. The classes that allow me to do so (NewProjectCreationOperation, PluginFieldData etc.) are internal and I was not able to find a public way to do so.
Finally, I'd like to be able to extend the new plug-in project wizard to automatically have my template selected on the templates page. I was sort of able to do so. In the class TemplateListSelectionPage I was able to pass in my template id. When the templates page opened the description of my template was displayed in the field, but my template was not selected in the list. Again, I had to use internal classes to get this far.

bug.short_desc: [Memory View] Memory monitor list is blank after re-launch a debug session

long_desc.thetext: After terminating a debug session and re-launch, the memory monitor list is blank until you add a new monitor, than the existing monitor is redraw in the tree view.

Hi Patrick,
Can you clarify what "memory monitor list" mean? Do you mean the list from the "Add Memory Monitor" dialog?
Maybe, can you describe the steps to reproduce the problem? and what you would expect ?
Thanks... Samantha

I mean the monitor tree view. It is blank after you restart. The problem is that when the view tries to restore the view pane by calling restoreViewPane(), the selection in the debug view is null, so setInput is null.
I would expect to see the previous entered monitor expression visible in the tree view without changing the selection.
The step to reproduce it will be launch a debug session, add a monitor, terminate the session and re-launch.

So, is this what's happening?
1. Add monitor, e.g. &i 2. Terminate Debug Session 3. Somehow &i is restored in the Memory View, but the tree viewer remains blank. 4a. Add monitor &k -> The memory view shows both &i and &k? or 4b. If you select a debug element from the Debug View, &i will show up.
Thanks... Samantha

correction:
2. Terminate Debug Session 2b. Restart debug session 3. Somehow &i is restored in the Memory View...
If you only have one monitor setup, the last one is restore in the view, but the tree view is still blank. When you add a new monitor or select a debug element, than the tree view is restore.

Already fixed in 3.2
http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/platform-debug-dev/msg00985.html
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 136646 ***

bug.short_desc: [Memory View] Last active memory monitor is not save after re-launch

long_desc.thetext: If you have multiple memory monitor setup, re-launching a debug session, and the last active memory monitor is not selected, it seems like the first memory monitor is selected from the list.

Patrick,
Is this your scenario? 1. Set up a few memory monitors 2. Terminate and relaunch the same debug session 3. Somehow, the memory monitors list is restored.
When the memory moniotors are restored, the first memory monitor is selected.
The expected behavior: The memory monitor that was previously selected should be selected.
Thanks... Samantha
Yes, that is my expectation.

The platform does not currently persist any memory blocks from previous debug sessions. It is up to the client to preserve the list and re-create the memory blocks when a debug session is started.
Similarly, we cannot persist selections between debug session. It should be up to the clients to restore the selection once the memory blocks are re-created.
Marking bug as won't fix.

bug.short_desc: [Memory View] Open rendering is not save between debug session

long_desc.thetext: The memory rendering is not save between debug session, so it is painful to have to open the same rendering over agin between debug session.

Patrick,
Currently, it is the client's responsibility to persist memory monitors and renderings between debug sessions. Are you using CDT ? If so, I would move this bug to CDT.
Thanks... Samantha
Yes, I am using CDT.
The platform does not save and restore memory renderings. Moving this bug to CDT.

bug.short_desc: Ant build failures during generic server publish need to generate an error IStatus

long_desc.thetext: Currently, a failed Ant executing during generic server publish will not result in an error IStatus being returned from AntPublisher.publish() since an exception is not being thrown from runAnt() and no other mechanism is included to test the Ant results; this has the result of setting the incorrect module publish status when the module failed to be published (and thus incorrectly resetting the publish delta).

bug.short_desc: [Internal API] Please consider making org.eclipse.ve.internal.cde.core.CustomSashForm public

long_desc.thetext:
Our editor uses org.eclipse.ve.internal.cde.core.CustomSashForm to divide two separate embeded editors.
Please consider making the class public, as it could be very useful for embeded editors.
Thanks.

bug.short_desc: Provide a checkbox to segueway into end-to-end scenario

long_desc.thetext:
With the WTP 1.5 Web service wizard, users must change the client slider in order to enable an end to end scenario. One of our users got confused in https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=150560 where they expected a proxy to be generated but one was not. Giving users the slider with develop as the first option is too flexible and will make them confused.
I think the client scenario is mostful useful if the client side is executed to deploy so perhaps a checkbox to enable the end to end scenario with the default client side being deploy might be better.
We currently don't have any plan for this RFE. We could reconsider if the community see this as an important enhancement and is willing to contribute resource to it.

Now close the edited file and open it in another editor, you will see that all the changes are lost!!! So Eclipse can't save outside the workspace. But it does let the user edit the file. Eclipse even lets the user save the file without an error message that the file cannot be saved.

I'm experiencing the same thing under Windows XP. I opened an external HTML file, made tons of changes, saved it, but nothing was saved and lost all of my work. I am currently unable to save any edits to files outside of the workspace.

I tried to reproduce this bug in Eclipse 3.2, Eclipse 3.2.1 and Eclipse 3.3M5 on Windows XP, but without success. Maybe you had some specific plugin installed? What happened when you closed the file in Eclipse and reopened it in Eclipse? Was there something in the .log file?

bug.short_desc: Add org.jcraft.jsch plugin jar to classpath for ANT plugin

long_desc.thetext:
The optional ANT tasks scp and sshexec depend on org.jcraft.jsch. The default installation of Eclipse 3.2 contains the jsch plugin, but the ANT plugin does not reference this. As a result, the scp and sshexec tasks do not execute.
Suggestion: modify the ANT plugin manifest to reference the org.jcraft.jsch plugin jar so that the scp and sshexec commands will execute.

Thank you for the enhancement request.
What is required is to add the jcraft classes to the Ant runtime classpath. This is most easily achieved by using the Ant core extraClasspathEntries extension point.

There might be a little more to it than just extending extraClasspathEntries.
I created the plugin.xml shown below and added it to the com.jcraft.jsch plugin jar. Then I restarted eclipse and tried my build. When I ran my build.xml file, ANT informed me that the scp task was not found: "Ant could not find the task or a class this task relies upon."
The jsch plugin is distributed as a jar, and the classes are contained as an exploded directory structure instead of a jar, so the library attribute of the extraClasspathEntry has to specify "." or "/". Neither of these forms resulted in the jsch plugin classes being available on the ANT classpath.
I checked the plugin registry view to see if the jsch plugin is listed as one of the contributers to org.eclipse.ant.core.extraClasspathEntries and it did not show up.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <?eclipse version="3.0"?> <plugin> <extension point="org.eclipse.ant.core.extraClasspathEntries"> <extraClasspathEntry library="."/> </extension> </plugin>

Is there a workaround I can apply in order to be able to run sshexec task under eclipse 3.2.1?
I'm trying to impress some people here in the company to migrate our development to eclipse, and this would much enhance the process.

Window>Preferences>Ant>Runtime>Classpath>Global Entries Add External JARS... Add the required JARs to the classpath as listed at http://ant.apache.org/manual/install.html#librarydependencies (the jsch.jar)

(In reply to comment #4) > Window>Preferences>Ant>Runtime>Classpath>Global Entries > Add External JARS... > Add the required JARs to the classpath as listed at > http://ant.apache.org/manual/install.html#librarydependencies (the jsch.jar)
Any chance jsch.jar will be added to the global Ant Runtime Classpath for 3.3?
Consider depending on time. Patches will be reviewed and considered.

no further enhancements are planned for 3.3

bug.short_desc: Quic filter for Package Explorer and Project Navigator views

long_desc.thetext:
I wonder if for Package Explorer and Project Navigator views, quick filter (see filtered tree API) could use the same search engine as used by Open Type dilog (and which supposed to be used by Open Resource dialog as well).
So, when filter is not empty, whole model of the navigator could be temporarily switched to something that would use that search engine underneath and still provide hierarchical representation.
Mylar plugin already can do filtering of those views, so this would be quite similar, but instead of Mylar's filter, filter would use search results.

In essence, do you suggest to add a filter box to the package explorer? Can I set this as duplicate of bug 149110?
Would this filter only apply to types? Or only to file names? Or also to members like fields and methods. The last one is problematic as I don't we can provide all these elements quick enough.

Yes, but it would be nice to have an option to hide that text box.

I think it should be configurable to show types and/or file names.
> The last one is problematic as I don't we can provide all these elements quick > enough.
Agreed.

bug.short_desc: Create a common interface between Table and Tree

long_desc.thetext:
Create a common interface between Table-Tree, TableItem-TreeItem, TableColumn-TreeColumn to allow classes to work against either widget. This will allow for simplification of the JFace viewers. It will also allow the Nebula Grid to implement the same interfaces and utilize the viewers as well.
See bug 149193.
Could abstract classes be used rather than interfaces?

I'm assuming you want to avoid the problem of brittle interfaces? i.e. interface2, interface3, etc...
An abstract class is ok as long as its design doesn't preclude a class other than Table or Tree extending it.

This has come up before and the consensus has been to not add such interfaces to swt. SN if anything has changed here then please reopen this report. In the meantime marking as a duplicate.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 4394 ***

We may yet to do this with an abstact class. We wouldn't do this with an interface for reasons that go beyond the scope of this bug report. There is a move afoot to add a Header and HeaderItem class (but this is waiting on the 3.3 plan). It's possible that TableColumn and TreeColumn would be subclasses of this.

<voice type="Homer Simpson>wahoo!</voice>
btw, I would be interested to hear the reasoning behind avoiding interfaces out of curiousity (brittle? added complexity for little gain? having to enforce exact behavior between classes?). Maybe it could be a blog post.

bug.short_desc: Proposal of Service Event Delivery Improvement

long_desc.thetext:
I found current service event delivery mechanism is inefficient; - All ServiceListener need to check if their filters match any ServiceEvent. - It causes performance degradation of any operations following ServiceEvents. (register/modify/unregister services)
Although filter supports one without specifying objectClass, most of ServiceListeners have particular objectClass intended (without arbitrary expression "*").
Therefore, I tried to modify the implementation as follows: --- 0. Framework keeps Hashtable ( key = class name, value = bundleContext lists) 1. When addServiceListener is called, check class name and set the bundleContext into the table. If there is no particular objectClass in its filter, key "Framework.NullClazz" is used. 2. When ServiceEvent whose objectClass ={classA,classB} is born, filter matching check against ONLY ones of listeners that bundlecontexts registered with (classA or classB) or without any particular objectClass. --- Let me show how it works using an example. If there are 3 bundles register 5 listeners, - Bundle1 registers listener1 with filter=(objectClass=serviceA) - Bundle1 registers listener2 with filter=(&(objectClass=serviceA)(test.msg=msgA)) - Bundle2 registers listener3 with filter=(objectClass=serviceB) - Bundle3 registers listener4 with filter=(objectClass=serviceB) - Bundle3 registers listener5 with filter=(test.msg=msgC)
CaseA: a ServiceEvent with (objectClass=serviceA,test.msg=msgA) will be check against filters of listener1(t)/listener2(t)/listener4(f)/listener5(f) (t represents "filter.match()=true", f represents "false")
CaseB: a ServiceEvent with (objectClass=serviceB,test.msg=msgB)will be check against filters of listener3(t)/listener4(t)/listener5(f)
CaseC: a ServiceEvent with (objectClass=serviceC,test.msg=msgC)will be check against filters of listener4(f)/listener5(t) --- Please see the patch in detail.
I'll show some performance test results later.

Created an attachment (id=46733) Excel file of performance test result comparison
The attached excel file shows performance test results between the posted patch applied and not.
See the excel file in detail. Briefly speaking, the differences are as follows;
-BundleContext#getServiceReference(clazz): -BundleContext#getServiceReferences(clazz,filter): - BundleContext#getService(reference): -> seems no difference.
- BundleContext#registerService(clazz, object, props): -> gets faster into appro. 77% ( 23% down). - ServiceRegistration#unregisterService(): -> gets faster into appro. 71% ( 29% down).
- ServiceTracker#open() -> gets slight slower into appro. 100%-104% (0-4% up).
- ServiceTracker#getService() -> seems no difference.
- ServiceTracker#close() -> gets slight slower into appro. 100%-102% (0-2% up).
Remarks: all results are average values among 100 runs. Please keep it in your mind that difference of several percentage might be assumed as the margin of error of tests.

Created an attachment (id=46735) Patch of ServiceTracker implementation suitable for Bug 151645
If the posted patch for ServiceEvent delivery mechanism is acceptable and Eclipse specific ServiceTracker implementation is acceptable, I have additional proposal of improvements regarding this topic.
First of all, current ServiceTracker doesn't set listenerFilter specifying objectClass when constructed with reference or filter.
Now, I propose the attached patch, which makes ServiceTracker to use listenerFilter for (objectClass=xxxxxx) proactively in order to make efficient use of the new ServiceEvent delivery mechanism to the utmost extent.
# objectClass will never be changed once registered. cf. Bug#144783.
I believe it results in drastic performance improvement. I'll show some performance test results in few days.

Created an attachment (id=47945) Excel file of performance test result comparison(v2)
Attached excel file shows performance test result using the patch of attachment 46735. As you can see, both registering services and unregistering become much lighter than before because of new ServiceTracker implementation.

Created an attachment (id=47977) different approach for service events
I have some issues with the first approach. It seems to artificially improve performance if you bundle has a small number of listeners. But if each bundle has a lot of listeners then the performance improvements may not be as big. Every service event is still delivered to each FilteredServiceListener registered with a bundle context (once we have determined that at least one of the listeners cares) even though all of the listeners do not care about the ServiceEvent. You also run into trouble if your bundle has a null filter listener.
This patch uses the same basic idea put forth by Ikuo but instead of keeping the EventListeners list in the context for each bundle it consolodates the listeners into the Framework class and keeps the EventListeners hashed by objectClass string and BundleContext. It no longer does a double dispatch to each context to collect a list of listeners.
One downside to this approach is that listener removal takes more time. This should not be a problem. As a best practice listeners should not be added/removed over and over. This also implies that ServiceTrackers are not opened and closed over and over (some code in Eclipse does this still ...).
Ikuo, can you run your performance tests with this patch? thanks.

I reviewed the patch.
(In reply to comment #8) > Created an attachment (id=47977) [edit] > different approach for service events > > I have some issues with the first approach. It seems to artificially improve > performance if you bundle has a small number of listeners. But if each bundle > has a lot of listeners then the performance improvements may not be as big. > Every service event is still delivered to each FilteredServiceListener > registered with a bundle context (once we have determined that at least one of > the listeners cares) even though all of the listeners do not care about the > ServiceEvent. You also run into trouble if your bundle has a null filter > listener.
That's right. When I posted, I had another approach that prevents this problem, in which BundleContext keeps Hashtable keyed by clazz --> filteredListeners in its double dispatch mechanism. However, it seemed to me troublesome because of the double dispatch used. That's why I hesitated to post it.
> This patch uses the same basic idea put forth by Ikuo but instead of keeping > the EventListeners list in the context for each bundle it consolodates the > listeners into the Framework class and keeps the EventListeners hashed by > objectClass string and BundleContext. It no longer does a double dispatch to > each context to collect a list of listeners.
Great! The code is very simple without double dispatch. I should have thought more simply (>_<).
> One downside to this approach is that listener removal takes more time. This > should not be a problem. As a best practice listeners should not be > added/removed over and over. This also implies that ServiceTrackers are not > opened and closed over and over (some code in Eclipse does this still ...).
Agree.
> Ikuo, can you run your performance tests with this patch? thanks.
OK. My current tests, which I run with previous versions, might not be best suitable to measure effectiveness of this patch ( While this patch is more effective in case that there are a lot of bundles each of which registers many ServiceListeners, the tests are not for it). However, I'll run them for comparison.

Created an attachment (id=48096) different approach for service events (against HEAD)
I released the patch in bug 149863. This causes conflicts in the latest patch. Here is an updated patch against HEAD.

Created an attachment (id=48113) Modified Tom's patch including suitable ServiceTracker Impl
Since I don't have enough time to run full test (I'll take long holidays from tomorrow and next post would be after Sep 6), I run some performance tests in which results are average values among not 100 runs but 10 to grasp its tendency against both codes applied the patch which Tom posted and with suitable ServiceTracker implementation. For the latter test, I used this patch (only change is setting modifier of FilteredServiceListener.getSpecificObjectClass to public). I'll show some results in the next post.

Created an attachment (id=48116) Excel file of performance test result comparison(v3)
As you can see, the patch Tom posted has a performance problem: time required for closing ServiceTracker becomes 160 times as slow as before (removing ServiceListener takes much more time than before). The degration went beyond my expectation...For instance, if there are 20 services to be tracked by a ServiceTracker, closing one tracker takes 27msec for this environment.
Don't forget that one bundle opens many ServiceTrackers for various services in the test.

To be clear the performance bottleneck is in any kind of ServiceListener removal (including ServiceTracker.close).
You should be able to improve ServiceListener removal by hashing the ServiceListener with the specific objectClass string used by its corrosponding FilteredServiceListener when the ServiceListener is added. This way upon removal you know what the objectClass string is and you can pass that to Framework.removeServiceListeners(context, listener, objectClass)
This should prevent you from having to iterate over the complete list of service objectClasses in Framework when removing the ServiceListener. Ikuo, can you modify the patch to try this approach?

Created an attachment (id=48138) Modified Tom's patch (ikuo-v3) including suitable ServiceTracker Impl
I modified Tom's patch which removes ServiceListener efficiently. In order to hash ServiceListener with the specific objectClass, we have to know the specified objectClass for the ServiceListener to be removed. To know it, there are two options (While FilteredServiceListener contains filter information, listener specified by BundleContext.removeServicelistener() does not.); Option 1. BundleContext maintains Hash keyed by listener --> specified objectClass. or Option 2. Framework maintains Hash keyed by (bundleContext, listener) --> objectClass. I choose option2 because maintaining many Hashtable or HashMap for each BundleContext seems troublesome.
I'm now running some tests for it.

Created an attachment (id=48145) quick listener removal (v4)
This patch is more along the lines of what I was thinking ...
I really think it simplifies things if this accounting is stored in the BundleContext. I want to avoid making inner classes like ListElement public. This patch makes FilteredServiceListener a KeyedElement so that we can quickly get the FilteredServiceListener using its wrapped listener as a key. This allows us the get the FilteredServiceLister when removing the original ServiceListener so we can get the specific objectClass used for the listener.
The KeyedHashSet should be relatively fast and small compared to using a HashMap so it should not be a big deal to keep one for each BundleContext.

Created an attachment (id=48146) quick listener removal (v4)
oops last patch has a bug. It did not remove the filteredServiceListener from the KeyedHashMap.
Ikuo, can you also clean up the ServiceTracker patch so that it only includes the code you changed. The current ServiceTracker patch has a lot of formatting changes and it is hard to see what really changed.
(From update of attachment 48138) It seems not work properly. I have no time to investigate the reason for two weeks from now on.Therefore, I make it absolete at this time.

Created an attachment (id=48151) Modified ServiceTracker for Tom's patch.
(In reply to comment #16)
> Ikuo, can you also clean up the ServiceTracker patch so that it only includes > the code you changed. The current ServiceTracker patch has a lot of formatting > changes and it is hard to see what really changed.
Sorry, but I am not sure why my patch includes a lot of unnecesary stuff e.g. whitespace (I'm using core formatting and whitespace ignore setting).
In addition, I have no time to run tests for the latest one and I'll be out next two weeks. So, Please leave this topic as it is by the time I am back at work on Sep 5. Sorry for your inconvenience.

Created an attachment (id=48177) ServiceTracker Patch
I removed all javadoc/comment/code format changes. The OSGi Alliance has a drastically different code formatter from the Equinox team. We do not want to change the format of the osgi supplied code. But it is very tempting ... just look at the following lines from ServiceTracker ...
Object property = references[i] .getProperty(Constants.SERVICE_RANKING); int ranking = (property instanceof Integer) ? ((Integer) property) .intValue() : 0;
Can you read that ;-) Anyway I recommend you just change only the lines you need to and never format the OSGi Alliance code.

Created an attachment (id=48198) Fixed ServiceTracker patch
Fixed ServiceTracker patch. The ServiceTracker created invalid filters (the filtere was missing a closing ')')

Created an attachment (id=48302) quick listener removal (v5)
This patch includes the latest ServiceTracker patch plus the quickListener removal patch.
This latest patch hashes ServiceListeners by identity hashcodes (System.identityHashCode(listener) instead of using ServiceListener.hashCode method. This is necessary because classes can override the hashCode() method to return different results (See the javaDoc for java.util.Map#hashCode). Using a ServiceListener as a key in a HashMap/HashTable is dangerous because we do not know how that object handles hashCodes. For example ServiceTracker$Tracked extends Hashtable and the hashCode for a Hashtable can change as you add/remove/change entries.
Something like a java.util.IdentityHashMap must be used for these types of scenarios. Unfortunately that class is not available in osgi ee.min. I've enhanced KeyedHashMap in the framework to be able to behave as an IdentityHashMap.

Created an attachment (id=50391) Excel file of performance test result comparison(for v5)
This excel file shows performance result for Tom's latest (v5) code and its effectiveness. In short, 1. registering and unregistering services take less time, 2. opening ServiceTracker (adding ServiceListener) takes less. On the other hand, 3. closing ServiceTracker takes more time a bit, which is acceptable.
Created an attachment (id=52058) latest patch against HEAD

Created an attachment (id=52075) new approach
In discussing and reviewing this bug with BJ we came up with an alternative approach. A much simplier approach would be to add logic to FilteredServiceListener to do a quick test on simple objectClass filters. This approach greatly simplifies the code and makes it much easier to understand.
BJ is going to do some more reviews on the ServiceTracker changes and attach additional changes.
Ikou, please rerun the tests with the next patch which should come from BJ's review of ServiceTracker. Thanks.

Created an attachment (id=52097) Improvement to new approach
I took Tom's new approach patch and reworked it and validated it. I also made some other minor perf improvments to the FilterImpl class (Vector => ArrayList). I changed FilteredServiceListener to avoid using the user supplied filter string if it was of the simple form "(objectClass=some.Clazz)". I also changed it to check the service's classes if forward order since ServiceTracker will use the first name. This should make the loop exit on the first iteration. I also made some other improvements to ServiceTracker.
When I ran with trace output and debugging on in ServiceTracker, then number of filter evaluation dropped dramatically. So the patch seems to meet the goal of short circuiting filter evaluations where possible.
I will let Tom review my updates, but I think this patch is good to go.
PS. We also need to apply the patch in bug 142385!

+1 the patch looks good.
Waiting for performance numbers from Ikuo.

Created an attachment (id=52145) Excel file of performance test result comparison(for BJv7)
I had run some performance tests (only the case of 20 services registered under each service name, among 10000 different service names).
As you find in the excel file, although the new approach improves its performance in some point compared to without any patch, it improves less than the previous version(v5) in any tests. I guess (no evidence)that even if FilterImpl and FilteredServiceListener are optimized, double dispatch mechanism using Framework.serviceEvent and BundleContextImpl.serviceEvent causes the inefficiency. What do you think ?

Created an attachment (id=52156) New approach patch updated with another improvement to ServiceTracker
I released this patch to HEAD. It updated my previous patch with another improvement to ServiceTracker to optimize filters of the form (objectClass=some.Clazz) into the simple class based ServiceTracker.
I will continue to examine this change with Ikuo's perf tests to see if there is some more improvement possible.

I had the following question from Tom this afternoon.
Q. First of all, Why ServiceTracker.open() performance of "applied patch (v5)" is better than the one of "without patch"? However, ServiceTracker.open will result in only getting current available services and addServiceListener.For these activities, v5 does much more complicated jobs than "without patch". v5 should be equavalent or more, shouldn't it?.
I found (remembered) the reason finally.
What the test does is "one" bundle (org.eclipse.osgi.test plugin) creates 10,000 ServiceTrackers with 10,000 different services (with different interfaces) in setUp() and open all of them in test() whose required time is measured.
In case of "without patch", BundleContextImpl.serviceEvent is a EventListeners and 10,000 pairs of listeners and filteredListener are added into the same EventListener object of the BundleContextImpl. (Line314 of BundleContextImpl.java). This job is very heavy because it is done sequentially in L104-109 of EventListeners.java.
On the other hand, in case of "v5", EventListeners#addListener(,) is also called 10,000 times. However each EventListener object are different and each size will be only 1 because Framework.serviceListenersByClass is a HashMap "keyed by objectClass->contextHash (HashMap); contextHash is keyed by BundleContext->EventListeners". Therefore each job is very light.
Make sense ?

If the test creates 10,000 bundles each of which creates a ServiceTracker for different service class, the result of ServiceTracker.open() must be changed. I guess v5 is slower than "without patch" and "new approach" because it has more overhead tasks for addServiceListener.
It seems to me that one of decision points in terms of ServiceTracker.open() will be the number of ServiceListeners which ONE bundle adds. If one bundle add so many ServiceLiseteners, v5 will have better performance. I'm not sure how many is the tradeoff points now.
If the way of v5(without double dispatch) and the way fo new approach (FilterImpl and FilteredServiceListener optimization) can be combined, it might be better.

(In reply to comment #29)
The explaination makes senses since EventListeners is a linked list data structure and does an O(n) search to detect duplicates. Since the v5 data structure is a hashmap of hashmaps the lookup is more like O(1). However the v5 data structure is memory hog since you end up with 10000 entries in the Framework.serviceListenersByClass hashmap (one for each unique service class). So v5 gets its O(1) lookup speed by consuming a lot of memory (10000 hashmap objects and 10000 EventListener objects).
However the test case is pathological since I do not think any reasonable bundle will register 10000 distinct listeners. I imagine the number of service listeners for any given bundle will be way less than 100.
Also the main point of this bug is to improve event delivery time not list modification time. So I think the gain observed here is artificial.

(In reply to comment #30) > It seems to me that one of decision points in terms of ServiceTracker.open() > will be the number of ServiceListeners which ONE bundle adds. If one bundle add > so many ServiceLiseteners, v5 will have better performance. I'm not sure how > many is the tradeoff points now.
Only if each ServiceListeners is for a distinct objectClass name. In the problem described in bug 142385, update configurator created hundreds of ServiceTrackers for the same objectClass. So even with the v5 data structure, all of the ServiceListeners would have ended up in the same EventListener and thus there is no benefit of the v5 data structure.
> > If the way of v5(without double dispatch) and the way fo new approach > (FilterImpl and FilteredServiceListener optimization) can be combined, it might > be better. >
I just do not see any bundle adding ServiceListeners for 1000s of distinct service names. Even if a bundle does registers a large number of ServiceListeners, they will be for a small number of service names (e.g. bug 142385). In this case the v5 data structure does not help much since you only end up with very few entries in Framework.serviceListenersByClass.

Closing this bug as fixed.
Thanks for the hard work on this one.
The latest code in HEAD shows a 4-5 times performance improvement of service event delivery. While this is not quite as good as the previous approaches it is still a very good improvement and as BJ points out, this approach uses much less memory which is also an important measurement here.
We could continue to investigate performance improvements for adding service listeners, but I'm not convinced there is much to gain from doing that. That work should likely be discussed in a separate bug report if you want to pursue it.

Created an attachment (id=52237) Excel file of performance test result comparison(for BJv8)
Unfortunately, tests for the latest BJ's patch, which Tom has already applied to HEAD, results in worse performance even Service Registration. Although I was wondered why and I recompile and rerun test, the result is same.
The difference between v7 and v8 must be only ServiceTracker. I'm not sure why. Do you have any idea ? >> BJ, Tom.

(In reply to comment #34)
The only change between the v7 and v8 pacthes is to ServiceTracker. (I confirmed this by redownloading the patch files and diffing them.) The the numbers for the NoST tests should have (near) identical number for v7 and v8. Yet your spreadsheet has wildly different numbers for the NoST tests...
Something must be wrong with your numbers/test methodology.

(In reply to comment #35) > Something must be wrong with your numbers/test methodology.
I deleted my project and download the whole current HEAD(it must be v8), compile it, and run short tests. Then, I got the almost identical results to v7.
Sorry for bothering. I'll upload final results in a day.

Created an attachment (id=52309) Excel file of performance test result comparison(for BJv8, revised)
I rerun the tests and got the expected results. Improving ServiceEvent Delivery mechanism contributes to (4 times) faster Service Registrations and so on, while ServiceTracker.open() and close() gets a little heavier (there are called only once for each). This improvement must be worthy.
