bug.short_desc: JointDataSet DnD from a library can't locate the corresponding datasets via JoinCondition

long_desc.thetext:
The namespace would be set to null when creating datasets in a library, which makes it impossible to locate the corresponding datasets via JoinCondition after dnd the jointdataset to a report which already contains a bunch of datasets differentiating from the ones from libary only in namespaces
Steps to reproduce: 1.Create a new libarary with a JointDataSet 2.Create a new report with DataSets sharing the name of the DataSets used by the above JointDataSet 3.DnD the JointDataSet to the report 4.Double-click the JointDataSet

In the above example, the requirements should be:
JoinConditionHandle.getLeftDataSet/getRightDataSet should return the namespace+the library dataset name.
Right?
Moreover, if fix this bug, will any other visible JointDataSet issue emerge? It is better to think about it first.
Yes,that's the requirement,regards
This is an big enhancment for Model to support the stucture reference structure. This need big code refactor.Will be schduled in 2.2.

Is it correct that a join data set can only join data sets in the same lib (or same report) as the join data set?
Hence, model can find the the data sets for the join data set using its name space/lib name. there is no need to use name space in the join condition.

The problem is: now a structure member can not reference an design element. The datasets list property on JointDataSet is a structure list. Now, each member of the dataset list is a string, which refer to dataset name. But this cause problem when you use the the JointDataSet in different scope, I mean the extend case.
User also can add the report dataset into the extended JointDataSet dataset list. So, we should not find all dataset according to the name space of the JointDataSet. If we simple add the name prefix to the dataset which is extended from the lib JointDataSet, that will cause other problem. Such as: the JoinDataSet named with Jds in library is extended from another lib one, then if you use the Jds in report. When you double click wants to edit your jointDataSet, you will set the data set in the data set list with strang name prefix(if we add the name space prefix, if we dont add it, as I mentioned before, we will not distinguish the report dataset that user added, and the lib ones). And other problems in command...
So the way to fix this issue is to let the structure property member can reference to a design element, which means the dataset list value is not a simple string, but a elementReferenceValue, which can keep all information to resolve the element. If so, it will be consistent with other reference behavoir and Model reference system can be used.

If drag a joint data set from library to report design, joinCondition.leftDataSet and rightDataSet must have library name space as prefix. Gave a temporary solution to support this feature.
Besides above, JointDataSet.CachedMetaData.resultSets also requires library name spaces as prefix. Also support it.
The implementation will be enhanced in next milestone.

bug.short_desc: make dependent bug reports show up as subtasks in task list

long_desc.thetext:
Say for example I have 4 bugs 1 - P3 - blocks 2 2 - P3 - depends on 1,3 3 - P4 - blocks 2, depends on 4 4 - P3 - blocks 3
In the task list, if the bugs are ordered by priority then the order is 1,2,4,3. But I think it would be useful if the ordering could take the dependencies into consideration ie. 1,4,3,2. That way we could just work on our tasks from top to bottom instead of always trying to think about what needs to be done first.
What do you guys think?

I'm marking as a duplicate of our subtasks bug report which is the mechanism by which we plan on showing the ordering of dependencies. I'll post my response there.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 137543 ***

On second thought, as long as you're OK with this approach David, let's use this bug as the driver.
Rob: please schedule this for next week.

I had no idea about bug 137543, after reading it I think it's also a good idea. Personally I think both (this ordering-based approach and also the subtask approach) would be great so that the user could use either depending on their situation.
Seeing as I'm the one who's asking for this functionality to be implemented and also the fact that it should be just a simple case of reording a list, rather than any complicated eclipse RCP work, I'm more than happy to impl this and submit a patch :) Could you please just give me a little starter? Whereabouts in the mylar code do you think I should I be looking?

Assuming that all you're after is the filtering functionality, start by looking at TaskListTableSorter. The implement a separate sorter class that does what you want it to do, and then we can discuss how to integrated it into the UI. You should provide a test case for your sorter that's similar to TaskListFilterTest.

Lol, I tried and failed and I'd better get back to work now. Sorry :)
I didn't get very far because of the restriction that you have to implement an interface that only allows u 2 compare 2 elements at a time. It would be much easier if u could perform a little post-processing on the list of items after they're sorted, imo. Anyways I suck, I'm sure u guys will have better luck with it :)
Doesn't look like I'll get to this this week - marking P3.
Pushing until post 1.0. At that time we will focus on getting the story right regarding task context and interaction with subtasks/categories and how repository dependencies play into this.
Tentatively scheduling this plan item for 2.0M3, since we will finally have the mechanism to support nesting in the view (bug 182772).

Added subtasks for Bugzilla (see BugzillaRepositoryConnector.updateTaskFromTaskData(...) ). Haven't done much interactive testing yet but have created bug#185901 to investigate how we're going to deal with overlap of activation and expansion icon for root tasks.

Cool! Two nits: 1) If bug B is a child of A, B will show both under A and under the query. I think that the content provider should be smart enough not to show it under the query node if a child of the query will show it? Otherwise we'll see many dependent bug twice. 2) Since this is still experimental I think it shold probably be an option in the Task List view menu, contributed by ..mylar.bugzilla.ui?
3) Subtasks need guaranteed visibility
I think we should make this API more flexible and allow multiple types of relations such as subtasks, dependent tasks, blocked tasks etc.
4) Subtasks need to be revealed in Scheduled mode

(In reply to comment #10) > 1) If bug B is a child of A, B will show both under A and under the query. I > think that the content provider should be smart enough not to show it under the > query node if a child of the query will show it? Otherwise we'll see many > dependent bug twice. Does this have the potential to break expectations since query results should be 'true' to the query. Additionally, if two hits within a single query have the same subtask this will lead to duplication as well.
> 2) Since this is still experimental I think it shold probably be an option in > the Task List view menu, contributed by ..mylar.bugzilla.ui? Done.
> 3) Subtasks need guaranteed visibility Parent task with interesting child now revealed but not expanding??
> 4) Subtasks need to be revealed in Scheduled mode Done.

(In reply to comment #14) > Does this have the potential to break expectations since query results should be > 'true' to the query. Additionally, if two hits within a single query have the > same subtask this will lead to duplication as well.
As long as the subtask shows anywhere under the query I think that it is being true enough to the query. There is a slight issue if it is collapsed by default, so perhaps subtasks should all be expanded by default to enforce this.
I don't see the hits having the same subtask as much of a problem since that kind of replication is necessary and should be less common.

Why is the action called "Filter Subtasks", or is that changing? I figure it should be called "Nest Subtasks" or "Hierarchical Subtask Presentation" because it should be rearranging the tasks to show subtasks as discussed. Or am I missing something? I just figure that if it's filter than we'll always want to leave it off because otherwise we'll always see multiple copies of the same task within the query. What we really want is the tasks visible under the query to show their child/parent structure.

It might be best do do this identically to how the Package Explorer does package presentation, i.e. with a submenu:
Subtask Presentation -> Flat -> Hierarchical

I like the hierarchical display but the + button conflicts with the activate button on my Debian system. I would like to add this for JIRA but JIRA has several notions of sub tasks: linked tasks which can have configurable relations and actual sub tasks (see comment 12). I think we should generalize the API and speak of related tasks rather than of sub tasks.

Steffen: could you please synch with the latest and upload the screenshot of the +/- toggle overlapping? I need to check if it's the same as our Suse 10.1 test setup.
Regarding subtasks, the connectors should be able to specify what relationship they want to use for nesting. For JIRA I'm guessing Subtasks is the right choice.
Created an attachment (id=67073) Subtasks on ubuntu
The core work went out with 2.0M3. Reducing task duplication is new bug 187156. Linux rendering is bug 186667.

bug.short_desc: Notify resource (Library) changes

long_desc.thetext: Add a method on SessionHandle to let GUI trigger a event as resource (library )changes. The ModuleHandle need provider way to register a listener to listen on this event and to be notified.

Model needs to provide an API on sessionHandle for GUI to set the changed library. Each library is corresponding to one or many reprot design handles which referenced it. For each report design handle, if one of the included library is changed, there should be an API to return the status for the library reloade.

Fixed. 1. Added IResourceChangeListener, LibraryChangeEvent. 2. Provide fireResourceChange(ResourceChangeEvent ev) on SessionHandle. 3. Added API reloadLibraries( ), reloadLibrary( String path ) on ModuleHandle.
Detail info, please reference java doc.

Need session level notification because add/remove moduleHandle is kind of resource change. For example, user export a library to resource path. This cuases a library add action in SessionHandle. GUI need way to listen on this changes to refresh GUI side accordingly.
Fixed as suggested.

bug.short_desc: Guard GDBCDIDebugger exception handling against null messages

long_desc.thetext: GDBCDIDebugger.newCoreException() methods throw an exception of their own if a Throwable is passed in whose message (Throwable.getMessage()) is null. The code should be guarded against this. I'll submit a patch.

Created an attachment (id=46743) Add guards against null messages
This patch adds guards against null messages in the Throwable.
No objections, Patch applied.
This just caught my eye: The check for exception==null in the first method is (was) useless, because exception is already used a few lines above.

I don't agree with you.
In
String message = MIPlugin.getResourceString("src.GDBDebugger.Error_creating_session") + exception.getMessage();//$NON-NLS-1$
the String operator + will not throw when a null argument is added. The resulting String then contains "null" as text.
But in
MultiStatus status = new MultiStatus(ID, code, message, exception);
the MultiStatus constructur does throw an IllegalArgumentException when the message parameter is null. This is due to an assertion several layers deeper in the software. The MultiStatus actively refuses to accept null messages.

(In reply to comment #4)
Yes, but the case exception==null will throw a NPE in the line
String message = MIPlugin.getResourceString("src.GDBDebugger.Error_creating_session") + exception.getMessage();//$NON-NLS-1$
I would suggest to check for exception==null either consistently (avoid NPE) or not at all (allow NPE). Considering that it is probably a programming error to pass a null exception, I'd go for the second choice.
BTW, this is quite independent of your patch and actually kind of cosmetics.

bug.short_desc: [modulecore] VirtualComponent.setMetaProperties never removes properties

long_desc.thetext:
When modifying an existing set of meta properties, VirtualComponent.setMetaProperties adds or replaces properties but does not remove properties that are no longer in the properties argument passed to the method. There is no alternate api for property removal.
Our application uses a non-fixed set of meta property keys including ones representing arrays (that have the array index appended) and allows the user to modify the set via property pages. The bug breaks this functionality in cases where key values should be removed.

I'm not sure if other people would agree that other properties be removed. This would be a change in a behaviour, so hence a change in API and this cannot be done in a fix release. For now, I added a method clearMetaProperties() on VirtualComponent. However, once again, I could not add this method to the IVirtualComponent interface because this would break all implementors of that interface and require them to define the method. So, you will just have to cast to a VirtualComponent and call the clear method, then call your set.
This is released to head and for the WTP 1.5.1 build for 072706.
Verified WTP 1.5.1 RC driver, closing.

bug.short_desc: Copy action should NOT add 'copy of' prefix

long_desc.thetext: Yes, I add this issue though it contradicts to issue #3985 and issue #33071. I really wonder what the advantage of this prefix should be. I never just wanted to create a copy where the name is not important like a backup. Whenever I copy a file I want to specify a new name. And there it is really annoying to remove the prefix over and over again. If this is now different for other people (otherwise it would probably not have been added this way) it might make sense to make this prefix configurable.

I agree, 'CopyOf' is mostly useless. But this has been done for consistency with the platform. We won't change that anymore. But I see this as a quite minor issue and don't think this justifies a new preference.

And changing it on the platform level will most probably neither happen?
(I only added it to JDT > UI as the other two issues concerning were classified the same way. Actually I want it to be changed for platform too as the "Copy of " prefix for non-Java files is also annoying.)

bug.short_desc: [DynamicUI] Bundle uninstall - [Fatal Error] :1:1: Premature end of file.

long_desc.thetext:
I have 2 plugins: Plugin A and B. A is the main pluging that contains "Application implements IPlatformRunnable". A has a perspective Pa and B contains another perspective Pb, respectively.
In A is an action X that tries to uninstall Bundle(B). Everything goes fine if there isn't any perspective extensions in plugin.xml (B). As soon as I declare at least one perspective in B an ErrorDialog pops-up and notifies with the following message: "Unable to load perspective", "Reason: Premature end of file".
Looking through the PerspectiveRegistry source I figured out that exception rised at line 164 when invoking "unableToLoadPerspective" method from mergePerspectives.
Regards, Cristinel Angheluta
Bug #152089 is a duplicate of this bug, says the same thing.
*** Bug 152089 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Comment from the other bug: http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.platform.rcp/msg15259.html
PW

(In reply to comment #0) > I have 2 plugins: Plugin A and B. A is the main pluging that contains > "Application implements IPlatformRunnable". A has a perspective Pa and B > contains another perspective Pb, respectively. > In A is an action X that tries to uninstall Bundle(B). Everything goes fine if > there isn't any perspective extensions in plugin.xml (B). As soon as I declare > at least one perspective in B an ErrorDialog pops-up and notifies with the > following message: "Unable to load perspective", "Reason: Premature end of > file". > Looking through the PerspectiveRegistry source I figured out that exception > rised at line 164 when invoking "unableToLoadPerspective" method from > mergePerspectives. > Regards, > Cristinel Angheluta
I think the problem comes from the removal of the plugin perspective extensions. I have the same error when I remove a perspective extension with the IExtensionRegistry. The error is launched in the PerspectiveRegistry by the preference listener, method mergePerspectives(PropertyChangeEvent).
Simon
I'm also seeing this problem in 3.2.1 when the dynamically uninstalled bundle contained a perspectiveExtension. However, I cannot reproduce the error in 3.3M4.

I'm also running into an "unable to load perspective"/"premature end of file" problem when trying to install one of the JDK sample apps from the Welcome page. This happens in ConfigurationActivator.installBundles()#182 (bundlesToUninstall[i].uninstall();), running Eclipse 3.2.2

bug.short_desc: Strange transform-then-clip behavior in OSX and Linux

long_desc.thetext: If you transform a GC then set a clipping area on it the results willl not be what you'd expect depending on the values given. I'll attach a testcase to illustrate what I mean. On Windows this works ok.

Created an attachment (id=46749) Testcase
The code opens a window with a canvas on it whose background will first be painted black. Then I add a transformation to the paint gc so that all coordinates will be scaled to half their values. I then clip the gc to the size of the canvas with the coordinates doubled so after the transformation they should be the original size. Then I paint the canvas red (also with the size doubled). What I'd expect to see is one red rectangle (this is the case on windows) without any black paint left. On OSX (and Linux) you see the black rectangle with a smaller one in red painted over it.
Problem is gone in latest Linux, still there in 3.3M6 OSX.

long_desc.thetext: Throwing an exception when no data can be exported or disable "ok" button in "Export Data" dialog
when no data can be exported, disable "ok" button in "Export Data" dialog

bug.short_desc: [JUnit] JUnit History should be sensitive to test class renaming

long_desc.thetext: When renaming a test, it would be useful for the JUnit history to be sensitive to the rename so that the renamed class appears in the history list.

I don't think we should rewrite history. :-) We have a time stamp there, and I think it should just represent the recording of what was actually run and with what result. If we start to update test names or test class names, wouldn't we have to update the test result as well?

:-)
actually, I think my real problem is that if I rename a test I just ran, and click on the run button to rerun the test again, I get an error saying that 'Test type does not exist'. Perhaps its not related to the history, just the junit runner?

bug.short_desc: Incorrect weaving of after returning when 'input' bytecode is of a strange form

long_desc.thetext:
We have had a user report a problem where after advice being woven into a particular method is producing code that does not verify. The problem occurs if the bytecode being input to the weaving process includes a subroutine that contains the return from the method.
Here is the problematic snippet produced by some unknown compiler: 200: invokespecial #17; //Method com/MyException."<init>":(Ljava/lang/String;)V 203: athrow 204: aload_3 205: astore 6 207: jsr 234 210: aload 6 212: areturn 213: astore 4 215: aload 4 217: invokevirtual #79; //Method java/lang/Throwable.printStackTrace:()V 220: jsr 234 223: goto 238 226: astore 7 228: jsr 234 231: aload 7 233: athrow 234: astore 8 236: aload_3 237: areturn 238: return Exception table: from to target type 2 213 213 Class javax/ejb/FinderException
2 226 226 any
see the jsr's jump to 234, but before the subroutine return at 238 there is an areturn out of the method (this method returns a String).
After weaving we get something like this:
200: invokespecial #17; //Method com/MyException."<init>":(Ljava/lang/String;)V 203: athrow 204: aload_3 205: astore 6 207: jsr 238 210: aload 6 212: astore 9 214: goto 248 217: astore 4 219: aload 4 221: invokevirtual #79; //Method java/lang/Throwable.printStackTrace:()V 224: jsr 238 227: goto 246 230: astore 7 232: jsr 238 235: aload 7 237: athrow 238: astore 8 240: aload_3 241: astore 9 243: goto 248 246: astore 9 248: invokestatic #299; //Method After.aspectOf:()LAfter; 251: invokevirtual #302; //Method After.ajc$afterReturning$After$1$26d6d4a7:()V 254: aload 9 256: return
see how the areturn has been lost - this code will blow up with a verify error (the string is on the stack, we just ignore it and 'return' normally)

the neatest fix here is that when we collect up the returns for a method, if this is a method with a non-void return type we don't try and use 'RETURN' - which is what happens at the moment in BcelShadow.
Whilst working on this I discovered a bug where duplicate RETURNs (second is harmless) are inserted in woven code for methods woven with a VOID return value. also fixing that.
fixes committed.
fix available.

bug.short_desc: [Model] Adding output to message breaks graphical view if there is documentation

long_desc.thetext:
SYMPTOMS:
Both input and output are missing from graphical view of operation after.
HOW TO REPRODUCE:
1. Add an operation 2. Remove output part of operation 3. Create documentation for *operation* 4. Add output part to operation
Both input and output are missing.
SOURCE OF PROBLEM:
<output> tag is added as first tag inside <operation>, even before <documentation>. However, according to the WSDL specs, the proper order is <documentation>?, (<input>|<output>|...)*.
Targetting WTP 1.5.4
There needs to be more information added here on why this should be accepted as an adopter hot bug. Is this a regression? Is it blocking adopter progress?
Adding a milestone target for review, please re-target appropriately.
Does not seem to meet stop ship criteria for WTP 2.0, please correct me if that is not the case.
I'm retargetting to 3.0. There is a workaround for this (move the documentation element as the first child of the Operation element).
Over to you valentin. This is model related. Thanks.
Will try to get a fix in for 2.0.1.
...and maybe also for 1.5.5.

Created an attachment (id=73325) Model patch for 1.5
Apply to org.eclipse.wst.wsdl

Created an attachment (id=73326) New unit test for 1.5
Apply to org.eclipse.wst.wsdl.tests

Created an attachment (id=73340) Model patch for 2.0
Apply to org.eclipse.wst.wsdl

Created an attachment (id=73341) New unit test for 2.0
Apply to org.eclipse.wst.wsdl.tests
Craig, can you please review so that we can submit for PMC approval.
Created an attachment (id=73695) added some comments to explain behaviour

Valentin, I approve. Your change looks good. I've added a patch with a few 'example' comments that should help us in future remember what this code is supposed to be doing. Please consider adding along with your code changes.

Problem:
The WSDL editor's graphical view will not properly render the document structure when the following scenario is executed:
1. Add a new operation 2. Remove the operation output 3. Using the properties view add documentation for the operation 4. Add the operation output
Cause:
The underlying WSDL EMF model's model to DOM reconciliation fails when adding the operation output and the operation has a child documentation element. The output element is added before the documentation element instead of after the input element.
Solution:
Skip the documentation element when determining the reference child after which the output element should be added. A new JUnit was added to test the scenario and prevent regression in the future.
Workaround:
Without this fix, the user will have to close and re-open the editor after executing the scenario.
Committed and released for WTP 1.5.5 builds > v200707191400
Bug 197302 was opened to track the change in the 2.0.1 stream.
This bug is now fixed for 1.5.5.
Closing.

attachment.desc: added some comments to explain behaviour

bug.short_desc: [WSDL Editor] Old <wsdl:message> are left in source if noone uses it

long_desc.thetext:
SYMPTOMS:
After adding and visual editing the operation, there are <wsdl:message> leftosvers.
HOW TO REPRODUCE:
1. Add an operation 2. Edit the message name of input part (using Properties view "New.."). 3. See the old <wsdl:message> left in file.
SUGGESTIONS:
It may be dangerous to automatically remove unused parts, as someone may lose information accidentally. However it seems logical to provide some kind of 'cleanup tool', which shows which messages are not used in the current WSDL and may be removed.
Agreed, this would be a nice feature. We often also leave inline schema element turds lying around after the releated operations have been removed.
Gabriel, I believe you did some work in this area. Is this by any chance fixed? If yes, can you please crossreference the bug and close this.

bug.short_desc: [content assist] proposal list should only popup above caret position after threshhold

long_desc.thetext:
I20060718-0800
The Content Assist popup list now appears above the caret position if there's not enough height available to show the popup with the stored size below the caret.
IMO, showing the popup above should only be the last resort if all else failed, since it forces the user to move his visual focus across the whole popup to see the first item (loss of context).
I'd like to have a threshold of, say, 10 items: When the list can still show 10 items if positioned below the caret, then it should be shown there (with reduced height to avoid overlapping the taskbar and such). Only if that's not possible, the fallback to show the list above be used.
Valid request.

bug.short_desc: [15][compiler] javac vs. JDT: getClass() returns Class<?> vs. Class<T>

long_desc.thetext: Maxime, Can you verify if this is an identified Sun javac's bug? Thanks

Why did you set this bug severity to critical? You should not have so places where this problem occur and moreover, it is easily workaroundable (just put the cast back after the "Clean Up"). Would you agree to reduce it to normal (or major if you really use the "Clean Up" very often)?

At the moment, I have to change it in 2 of 40'000 LOC. But only because I wrote an auxiliary static method (like the one in the example). So judge yourself how frequent this can appear in a code.
I agree for a reduction of the severity as I'm an bug commiter from outside.
It's interesting to see that if you let T be a subclass of Number, javac complains in this way:
incompatible types found : java.lang.Class<capture of ? extends java.lang.Number> required: java.lang.Class<? extends T> return object.getClass();
So javac makes erasure first. I don't see the point in differenciating between Class<? extends T> (with T extends Number) and Class<? extends Number> if the ereased return type is the type Class. Even if the return value of the method is assignable to Class<? extends Number>, why should there be internaly a restriction?
It would be nice to know what counts:
1. Class<? extends T> because this is correct if Java had no erasure 2. Class<? extends [raw type]> because Sun wants it so in javac
For me it looks like a bug in javac. If this would be the case, I don't think it was a mistake to fill this bug report. Who would expect that getClass() works wrong?

Should have been more proactive on this one, sorry. See bug 147381 for further comments.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 147381 ***
Verified for 3.3 M1 using build I20060807-2000.
Verified for 3.2.1 using build M20060915-1045

Please attach the hello bundle jar that is failing. My guess is that your Bundle-ClassPath is pointing to an "inner" jar that does not get included in your built bundle jar.

It does not depend on any inner jar.The thing is that i did not export it as a separate .jar.Just tried to install the plug-in project folder. e.g install reference:file:D:\sample\bundle1 where bundle1 - plug-in pjt folder
It got installed and even got resolved.So i expected it to run.Why it did not?

It does not depend on any inner jar.The thing is that i did not export it as a separate .jar.Just tried to install the plug-in project folder. e.g install reference:file:D:\sample\bundle1 where bundle1 - plug-in pjt folder
It got installed and even got resolved.So i expected it to run.Why it did not?

This is not valid.
PDE launches the framework in dev (using -dev <path to dev.properties>). The dev.properties file tells the runtime additional directories to add to the bundle classpath for particular bundles in your workspace. By default the plugin project uses the "bin" directory in your project to store built classes. When you install a bundle manually this extra bit of information is not passed to the framework.
If you really want to do this you can use a project the uses its root directory for the source and output location of your java classes. This way no additional "bin" directories need to be added at development time.

bug.short_desc: "Automatically restart servers when necessary" without effect

long_desc.thetext: Independent of the checkbox "Automatically restart servers when necessary" the server will always be restartet after a change to web.xml. Looking into the code shows that this preference is handled from the method ServerPreferences.isAutoRestarting(). I could not find a reference which uses this method. Is it still used? If so, which effect does it have?
I cannot reproduce this problem. Which server adapter are you using, and do you actually see the server state within the Servers view change to stopping and starting?

I am using the tomcat 5.5 server adapter.
Sorry, I got it wrong. The server will *not* be restartet after changes to web.xml. Instead, the status changes to restart. Which indicates that the user should restart the server. I understood the "Automatically restart servers when necessary" feature in that way, that it would support the user and restart the server automatically in that case (whenever the restart state is entered).
Instead, the servers are restarted immediately after checking "Automatically restart servers when necessary" and pressing OK on the preferences page. Which I think is quite startling since the term "Automatically" let me expect a little more sophisticated behaviour ;-)
Is that the intended behaviour? If so, is there another way to have the server restarted automatically (e.g. after the web.xml file has been modified)?

Ok, now I understand the problem. The preference is supposed to do two things: 1) Restart any servers that currently need restarting. (this is really just initial clean up) 2) Restart any servers in the future that need restarting. (this is the behaviour you expect - when you modify the web.xml it will automatically restart the server)
The second part went missing somehow. I'll use this bug to fix the behaviour.
Changes dropped to HEAD, will release for I-build shortly.
Fix has been released to 1.5.1 & 2.0 streams for next build.
Tested OK with wtp-sdk-M-1.5.1-200609221939. Thanks!
Closing.
This is part of a "mass update" where bugs showing "fixed" between 7/1/2006 and 9/27/2006 are assumed fixed in WTP 1.5.1. feel free to change the target milestone if you know a more accurate setting.

bug.short_desc: Closing comparison editor opened from local History view decrease interet on the resource

long_desc.thetext: When closing comparison editor opened from local History view (opened using doubleclick in Histoy view with compare mode turned on) Mylar decreases interest on that resource and as a result also closes an actual editor for the same file. This is quite distacting.

Similarly, when closing any editor, interest on the resource is decreased so much that the resource disappears from the view, is filtered away. This is very annoying for resources marked as Landmarks or resources that have a lot of interest. Would it not be possible to just reduce the interest a bit but not remove them entirely.
The reason why i am closing editors sometimes even though I am still interested in the resources, is that I want to be able to read what resource is open in the editor tab and if too many editors are open, this is impossible.

The policy is that if it is the last editor on that resource, closing it is indicative of not being interested in the resource. To fix this bug I made the closing of compare editors never reduce interest. This is an acceptable exception is comparing files is different than viewing/editing them.
Raphael: it is possible to turn off Mylar's editor management via the preferences. Our goal for this feature is that you never have to care about manually managing the set of open editors, so we want to direct all improvements at meeting that goal. You could submit a bug of the form "number of interesting editors is bloating", and give precise details of how many you're seeing, how many you'd like to see, and include the reason (e.g. your 2nd paragraph).
Created an attachment (id=50521) mylar/context/zip

bug.short_desc: [Markers] Problems Pane needs a filter for latest problems

long_desc.thetext:
[JDK1.5.0. eclipse.buildId=I20060602-1317]
When I right-click to build a project, the resultant Problems pane is cluttered with problems due to other projects.
Unlike netbeans, where I could clearly see the problems of only the current project or class.
When I get an programming idea, I normally would concoct a few incompletely coded classes together. The idea may even span across a few projects. But the clutter is not helping because of problems of all the other new classes appearing in the Problems pane. I need to perfect the coding one class at a time.
I don't wish to close projects just to hide their problems because that would require me to open/close projects every fifteen minutes (or so), as I need to work across a few projects, simultaneously, but compiling one class at a time.
It seems the Problems pane at its current status is akin to an engineer obsessively cc'ing an email all over the company for an isolated issue.
Didi you see that you can set filters to the problem view?

Since my style of programming is to quickly move from class/jsp to class/jsp quickly but wish to solve one at a time, does this mean I have to concoct a filter for each class/jsp and switch filters every few minutes.
Does this mean I have to maintain a whole bucket of filters and remember what they are for and remove them? Would I have to have as many filters as I have files. In that case, is there a filter navigator to help me identify a filter to the file I am about to work on?
Why not just be straight forward and provide a problems view of the current class being validated/compiled? The spirit of java is to avoid allocation and deallocation.
How about an icon button at the problems pane [Current Problem] for showing the problems associated with the last build/compile/validation?
The problem with netbeans view of build problems is that the last set of diagnostics are written over by another compile/build. So eclipse view is better iff (i.e., if & only if) eclipse Problems pane had such a button.
Note that there is a filter that limits the problems to the current selected resource and optionally its children.

I wish to persist in requesting for a drop down menu right at Problems pane to allow choice of: 1. filter on last attempt of build/validate/compile. 2. choose from list of working set. 3. configure/create working set filter.
As a chronic/manic programmer, I find it difficult needing to get in and out of a pop-up window to go thro unnecessarily repeated settings.
One of the filters available is "On any element in the same project" as well.
Please consider my posting at bugzilla #153306 .

Works ok. Please give specific example.
works fine

bug.short_desc: Using LineStyleProvider doesn't update region returned by damager

long_desc.thetext:
I'm using Callisto code.
Setup: I am writing an editor that is not suitable for use with a rule based scanner, so I am having to do all the parsing.
I have created a LineStyleListener to provide presentation information to the text widget. I have created one partition type (i.e. the document is all one partition) and a damager for that partition. I have not created a repairer.
Bug: 1. I edit the document in a way that will cause lots of coloring changes. 2. my damager gets called, and I return a Region that covers the damaged area. 3. unwinding the code, I see that in TextViewer.addPresentation(), a call is made to fTextWidget.setStyleRange(). The range has no presentation content (I don't think) but does contain the proper offset/length. 4. In StyledText.setStyleRange(), it does the following code: (isListening(LineGetStyle)) return;. Because the code kicks out early, the widget is not redrawn. 5. Scrolling text off the visible editor window and then back in makes it redraw correctly.

I don't think this has nothing to do with StyledText. When you install a LineStyleListener you can't use setStyleRange anymore, see the articles about StyledText in the eclipse.org. If all you need it to redraw the widget you sould be calling redrawRange(start, length).

So is it unsupported to use a Damager with a line style listener? Should the presentation reconciler framework be calling redrawRange() in this case?
When is it legal to call redrawRange()? I ended up calling it on an asyncexec because I didn't see any other hooks.
Should StyledText.redraw() work? It didn't seem to for me.

> So is it unsupported to use a Damager with a line style listener? I have no idea ? Damager is not SWT (actually, i never heard of it).
>Should the presentation reconciler framework be calling redrawRange() in this case? I have not idea. presentation reconciler framework is not SWT.
> When is it legal to call redrawRange()? I ended up calling it on an asyncexec because I didn't see any other hooks.
When you use LineStyleListener and you want the StyledText to ask back the style information for a range of text. Please, read the articles about StyledText.
> Should StyledText.redraw() work? It didn't seem to for me.
Yes, it works.
- - - - - - - -
Why did you moved this problem back to SWT ? I still don't know what is the problem you have.

I missed something last time.
>Should the presentation reconciler framework be calling redrawRange() in this >case? Yes, that is why I moved this problem to Text.

Felipe,
Thanks for your responses.
I'm moving this defect to Text per your response. I didn't intentionally change the category; sorry about that.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 147303 ***

bug.short_desc: [GlobalActions] [IDE] Allow to extend RefreshAction

long_desc.thetext:
I bug 82406, we're asked to replace our instance of a RefreshAction with RefreshAction from org.eclipse.ui.actions: - run refresh in the background - use the same prompting dialog
As a difference, the RefreshAction in jdt.ui additionally refreshes external Java libraries. Best would be if we could extend the RefreshAction and overwrite 'execute' to add the additional calls to the Java model.
execute is currently final and package protected.
This is a request to extend the refresh action provided by platform.ui

Martin, would you not just extend org.eclipse.ui.actions.RefreshAction#invokeOperation(*) (if I lift the restriction on subclassing, at least partially)? See bug 182105
Or is the problem that it won't tell you the libraries (although I assume if they refresh an IJavaProject you could find the external libraries)?
PW

Allowing to subclass RefreshAction and overriding invokeOperation(IResource resource, IProgressMonitor monitor) should work if the action specifies that it does all the work there. What's not so nice is that WorkspaceAction.invokeOperation is marked as deprecated.

(In reply to comment #3) > Allowing to subclass RefreshAction and overriding > invokeOperation(IResource resource, IProgressMonitor monitor) > should work if the action specifies that it does all the work there. > What's not so nice is that WorkspaceAction.invokeOperation is marked as > deprecated.
It would be possible to change invokeOperation(*) into a similar protected method that could be overriden. Then provide the RefreshAction createOperation(*) method instead and remove the run().
I would open this action up for subclassing within the eclipse SDK.
PW

Created an attachment (id=82457) RefreshAction v01
This will:
* Allow subclassing within Eclipse SDK * Rework the action in terms of createOperation(*) * Add a protected refreshResource(*) for JDT to extend
Will this work for JDT?
PW

That would work!
Two comments: 1. 'This class may be instantiated; it is not intended to be subclassed outside of the Eclipse SDK.'
Are you sure we need this limitation? I think that would be a first. I suggest to open it up for everybody.
2. From looking at your patch you just more or less had to duplicate createOperation and invokeOperation. So I wonder, why is 'invokeOperation' deprected at all? I don't really see the problem with it. Its good that users have the possibility to override createOperation and don't need invokeOperation, but what's the problem o just implementing 'invokeOperation'... I would remove the deprecation and allow both.

(In reply to comment #6) > That would work! > > Two comments: > 1. 'This class may be instantiated; it is not intended to be subclassed outside > of the Eclipse SDK.' > > Are you sure we need this limitation? I think that would be a first. I suggest > to open it up for everybody.
Well, none of the other resource actions allow subclassing (officially) and I certainly don't want to be adding/opening up new action API ... I'm a command guy, right :-) If there was a usecase for subclassing this action I'd be open to it, though.
> 2. From looking at your patch you just more or less had to duplicate > createOperation and invokeOperation. So I wonder, why is 'invokeOperation' > deprected at all? I don't really see the problem with it. Its good that users > have the possibility to override createOperation and don't need > invokeOperation, but what's the problem o just implementing > 'invokeOperation'... I would remove the deprecation and allow both.
Susan, could you answer #2?
PW

>If there was a usecase for subclassing this action I'd be open >to it, though. There are two use cases inside the SDK (this one and mine) and hence you can bet that there are clients outside the SDK who could profit from opening it. Opening it up just for the SDK sounds strange as Martin already pointed out.
To be on the safe side just make those methods public or protected that we currently need. Make the rest either private or package visible and if not possible because you cannot reduce visibility for some of the methods declare them final.

(In reply to comment #8) > There are two use cases inside the SDK (this one and mine) and hence you can > bet that there are clients outside the SDK who could profit from opening it.
I know people will take advantage of it. I wanted a couple of concrete customers outside the SDK. Remember, adding new action framework API is outside my mandate, except as it relates to 1) creating legacy bridges to the command framework and 2) fixing serious bugs.
But I'll take a crack at it full public.
PW

Created an attachment (id=82531) RefreshAction v02
OK, anyone can subclass, but functionality basically unchanged:
* extend refreshResource(*) to add extra refresh capabilities * extend or override getResources() and updateSelection(*) if necessary
PW
Released to HEAD >20071113 PW

> 2. From looking at your patch you just more or less had to duplicate > createOperation and invokeOperation. So I wonder, why is 'invokeOperation' > deprected at all? I don't really see the problem with it. Its good that users > have the possibility to override createOperation and don't need > invokeOperation, but what's the problem o just implementing > 'invokeOperation'... I would remove the deprecation and allow both.
>Susan, could you answer #2?
Sorry to answer after the fix, but just to close the loop... createOperation was introduced so that actions that support undo could specify an IRunnableWithProgress that creates an undoable operation. The undoable operations record the list of resources that were selected at the time and do the work on them as a group. So invokeOperation is no longer called by any action that is undoable, and invokeOperation was marked deprecated to encourage clients to instead provide operations that are undoable.
Since not all operations are undoable, the default implementation for WorkspaceAction implements createOperation in terms of execute, which still uses invokeOperation.
*** Bug 182105 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Created an attachment (id=82852) Get rid of 'abstract' in WorkspaceAction.invokeOperation
org.eclipse.ui.actions.WorkspaceAction.invokeOperation(IResource, IProgressMonitor) should be changed to be non-abstract and empty. That way you don't need to force subclasses into providing their own empty implementation as said in the Javadoc: * @deprecated Since 3.3, subclasses should instead implement the method * {@link #createOperation(IStatus[])} and provide an empty implementation * for this method.
This patch does that. I can commit it if you agree.
Looks good, Dani, go ahead. PW
Committed https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=82852 to HEAD. Available in builds > N20071114-0010.

bug.short_desc: loadtime5 and weaver5 modules missing from aspectjtools.jar

long_desc.thetext:
aspectjtools.jar is supposed to be a superset of aspectweaver.jar. Currently it is missing the Java 5 modules. A verbose output of the build gives a small clue as to why. It would seem that we copy ajbrowser-all.jar to become aspectjtools.jar. Unfortunately this module has not Java 5 dependencies.
... [ajbuild-copy] omitted as is up to date. [ajbuild-copy] lib added as lib doesn't exist. [ajbuild-copy] Copied 1 empty directory to 1 empty directory under C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\dist\tools [ajbuild-copy] Copying 1 file to C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\dist\tools\lib [ajbuild-copy] Copying C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\jars\org.aspectj.lib.jar to C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\dist\tools\lib\aspectjlib.jar [ajbuild-copy] Copying 1 file to C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\dist\tools\lib [ajbuild-copy] Copying C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\jars\aspectj5rt-all.jar to C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\dist\tools\lib\aspectjrt.jar [ajbuild-copy] Copying 1 file to C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\dist\tools\lib [ajbuild-copy] Copying C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\jars\ajbrowser-all.jar to C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\dist\tools\lib\aspectjtools.jar [ajbuild-copy] Copying 1 file to C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\dist\tools\lib [ajbuild-copy] Copying C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\jars\loadtime5-all.jar to C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\dist\tools\lib\aspectjweaver.jar created product in C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\aj-build\dist\tools [antcall] Exiting C:\workspaces\org.aspectj\build\build.xml.
BUILD SUCCESSFUL Total time: 5 seconds
Because we can't explicitly build JDK 1.4 code I have had to put the JDK 1.4 tracing implementation in weaver5. This means we can't trace the compiler with java.util.logging.

I would have expected that you could still use the implementation at runtime, as long as you have it on your classpath. Or do you mean tracing when running from inside of Eclipse
Since it's in weaver5, I believe it is being compiled with a 5.0 target, so you couldn't use it on a 1.4 VM. Is that right? If there's a commons logging provider, then hopefully that will let you use Log4j or Jdk logging.

There is not a problem in Eclipse because you have ajde, weaver and runtime and there shouldn't be any intersection of their contents (although I have just noticed some "lang" classes in both runtime and ajde). The issue concerns the commandline compiler or Ant where aspectjtools.jar only is used.
There is a Commons Logging provider which will works if you have that package installed. The idea of using JUL directly is that most people run JDK 1.4, it's simple to configure and has a rich interface and implementation (recursion protection, argument formatting). Unfortunately we can't build our provider with JDK 1.4 (yet) so it can only be used on Java 5.

"aspectjtools.jar is supposed to be a superset of aspectweaver.jar."
Not true. Only aspectjweaver.jar was supposed to have the loadtime stuff. The aj.bat script that uses aspectjtools.jar works with the weaver class loader (i.e., without loadtime). That's all clear in the project dependencies. The whole rationale for a separate aspectjweaver.jar is to *not* have the compiler when you're doing load-time weaving (and to prove to end-users that the weaver is distinct from the compiler).
If there is a reason that *end-users* require loadtime5/weaver5 in aspectjtools.jar, we can put it in by changing the dependencies. (I personally would do that by making an aspectjtools module and setting up the dependencies accordingly, rather than having a 1.3 module like ajbrowser depend on a java 5 module like loadtime5). But the rationale for this bug seems to be supporting JDK 1.4 logging in the compiler (comment #1), which really has nothing to do with the packaging of aspectjtools.jar.
I've said in conference calls that the build system doesn't currently support JDK 1.4 modules/projects - only 1.3 and Java 5. The current build system can be extended to do so, but since we're revamping the build system perhaps we should just design it in. However, AFAIK, we're sticking the JDK 1.3 for the compiler, so the logging for the compiler has to build under 1.3, so it looks like we have to do the same kind of interface and reflective loading we do in runtime, etc.
So the resolution is: - add java.util logging with aspect or interface/reflection(commons logging?) - we finish the build revamp - or a committer could change the dependencies in the short term [but I don't think that's the issue]
This should be closed as "Not a bug" (invalid in bugzilla)

Not being pedantic but the original Bug 73369 that added weaver.jar states:
"Several folks have asked for a jar file as part of the aspectj distribution that contains just the subset of aspectjtools.jar needed for load-time weaving."
Also having aspectjweaver.jar contain half of the loader and weaver modules (by leaving out the Java 5 code) is confusing and meant that we couldn't use JUL for the compiler. Unless there is a simple way to solve this I will close the report given we are working on a new structure and the temporary fix gives me what I need.

Bug 73369 was written and closed months before we even had the loadtime module, so at the time the bug was written LTW *was* a subset of aspectjtools.jar.
The correct solution to avoid any confusion would be to move the WeavingURLClassLoader etc. from weaver into loadtime, and use aspectj-weaver.jar even for aj.bat, but we didn't do that to avoid breaking user scripts.
I'm not averse to including all the loadtime stuff in aspectjtools, but I do think there should be an end-user use case for that. (I'm not sure what JUL is -- java.util.logging?)
Anyway, as you state I think this is incorporated in build/Restucture of AspectJ*.doc, so I'll close it.

bug.short_desc: appContext is null when evaluating parameters

long_desc.thetext:
On a report with parameters, during the resolution of the report parameters, datasource used to populate values of each parameters doesn't have any appContext.
We used a jdbcbridbe, and thru appContext, we're retrieving jndi name and others parameters usueful for our datasource. In those case, during the evaluation of parameters, appContext is null so the datasource used to populate values of the parameters are not from the same database ...
Could you please attach your report? Thanks.

The report is not the problem. I explain that I have a jdbcbridge that extends jdbc driver (the only solution to have post parameters and use the standard viewer). The jdbcbridge is based on setAppContext to catch parameters. When the engine creates the datasource to evaluate parameters of the report, the appContext send to the datasource is null.
The report can't helps you to evaluate this problem.
Please attach your report design for our investigation, since we need to know how report parameters are used in your report. Thanks.
Created an attachment (id=46803) Report with parameters
Created an attachment (id=46804) Jdbc Bridge (source plugin)
Maybe the jdbcbridge will helps you too.
Created an attachment (id=46866) Report with parameter
Created an attachment (id=46867) JDBC Bridge Plugin (eclipse project with export jar)

I have changed the code, you can use it well now. I sent a JDBC Bridge eclipse project containing also the export jar.
I put the plugin into birt viewer webapp (web-inf/plaform/plugins) and debug the jdbc bridge.
The execution of the report (http://localhost:8080//birt-fermat/frameset?__report=report\bug%20151694.rptdesign&SubJdbcJndiName=java:comp/env/jdbc/dbProduction) use a jndiName to execute the report with a datasource that is not the one detailled in the report.
Parameters values that are proposed are extracted from the datasource detailled in the report. After selecting a parameter value, the execution of the report is done on the datasource of the jndiName.
When debugging, appContext is called several times with the waiting value for the exection of the report but not the same for the parameter execution.
If not, tell me which BIRT version you are using.

There is a bug existing in current code so that the appContext of a GetParameterDefinitionTask (derivers of IEngineTask) cannot be properly deliver to driver in case the parameter is acquired from data sets. This bug is fixed.
However, we still do not know whether the fixing of the mentioned bug can solve the problem you meet, for we cannot reproduce the test environment of your case. Could you please use the latest builds from CVS (build date should later than 8/1/2006) to see if the problem is fixed.
Please also verify that in your test environment the appContext is set to GetParameterDefinitionTask using method IEngineTask.setAppContext() before the values of parameters are evaluated.
Thanks.

I submit new elements from my environnement ...
And I soon said that i use standard servlet to run my reports. I don't have the hand on setting IEngineTask.setAppContext(...), it's viewer code that set this, not me. I don't have any code like the one you submit. It's BIRT frameset servlet that does this.
Also, it's not really my aim to use the last CVS code, and recompile each time the viewer. The designers who works with me, use 2.1.0 version. I have to use the same one and be sure that bugs we encountered and which i report will be resolved in next versions.
My environnement is standard, you just have to take the plugin, the report, debug the plugin when laucnhing the report and you will encountered the same bug, or not if it have been fixed. You're asking me to download and compile a new version of BIRT according that it's a trunk one and ...
Which plugin ? There is no nightly and no branches since one month ... Did you want me to download the whole CVS ?

There are two ways to set up appContext for a report. One is to use IEngineTask.setAppContext() methods, the other is by visiting _jsContext JS object.
Could you please tell us the way you pass the appContext from your application to us?This may help us to find the source of problem.
BTW, As you mention in previous posts, you pass a parameter "SubJdbcJndiName" with value "java:comp/env/jdbc/dbProduction" to servlet. (http://localhost:8080//birt-fermat/frameset?__report=report\bug%20151694.rptdesign&SubJdbcJndiName=java:comp/env/jdbc/dbProduction). But I cannot find a parameter defined in the report you attached with name "SubJdbcJndiName".Is that some parameter defined interal by your product?
Thanks.

The plugin you need to update would be org.eclipse.birt.report.engine, however, if you still use release version 2.1.0 I am afraid that you've to download the lots of other plugins as well for lots of changes have been made after that.If that brings you lots of troubles you may simply tell us the way you pass the appContext so that we can mimic the context in your environment.
As in our tests, appContext which is passed through IEngineTask.setAppContext() has already function. And this method is the start point of all appContext that can be finally passed to the driver.

I only use parameters of the HttpRequest. The client which called the viewer is on another webapp maybe on another server, so I just set a parameter when redirect to the BIRT webapp.
In setAppContext I just retrieve the HttpRequest that is stored in appContext.

So you mean the parameters are passed to your driver through appContext, and that appContext is set by someone else?The BIRT web viewer would not set the parameters passed by HttpRequest to appContext (actually it would not set any appContext for birt engine) and all appContext should be set by API caller.
So if the problem still reproducible after my last check in then the source of problem might be 1)There are still some problem in BIRT that prevent an appContext being set to engine task correctly.However until now our test shows the appContext works correctly ( after my last check in) 2)The client of BIRT api has not called IEngineTask.setAppContext() method so that the appContext, which is supposed to contain parameter information, cannot function.
I will continue to test the appContext in BIRT.

appContext set by the viewer, CONTAINS some parameters and one is HttpRequest.
This appContext was sent to the driver during the execution of the report and not during the execution of the parameters evaluation.
I always mean in a webapp context, under eclipse I did not care and i don't think HttpRequest is set ...

Based on your comments #2 and #18, you want the appContext to be passed to driver before the report parameters being set.
However, BIRT viewer does not handle appContext. The appContext should be set by engine api caller. The clients of BIRT engine api decide whether and when to pass appContext to driver.
Before my check in, even if the api caller set up the appContext for parameters, this appContext still won't work. This is however fixed by my check in.
Because you are not the engine api caller, I would like to suggest that: a)Talk to team which deals with engine apis to see if they called IEngineTask.setAppContext() correctly, if they are easily reachable for you. b)Wait till your product used latest BIRT release, that is, the release contains my check in.
BTW, can you explain last part of your HttpRequest, that is "SubJdbcJndiName=java:comp/env/jdbc/dbProduction" to me? This is used to pass a parameter "SubJdbcJndiName" with value "java:comp/env/jdbc/dbProduction". If it is delivered to BIRT web viewer we will explain it as a parameter value and set it to report parameter directly.I cannot find this parameter in your attached report.
I think this bug has been fixed.You could solve your case as Lin suggested. If the bug still exist, please reopen it. Thanks.

It is a little bit annoying to reselect the tree and to reopen the actual category to fix the next bug. In my opinion it would be better to select the next bug.
Tod, could this be caused by the fact that you create new parent nodes all the time instead of reusing the existing ones?
No - the categories should reopen if they are still valid. I suspect this is a corner case my existing algorithm missed.

bug.short_desc: API additions to support J2EE binary modules in EAR

long_desc.thetext:
The J2EE team added support for including binary modules directly inside the EAR project so that teams working on an EAR do not need to import every module in the EAR when working on it. However, while doing this it broke the binary module support for servers - binary modules are no longer returned from jst.j2ee so servers have no way to publish them, and similarly API clients have no way to find these binary modules.
For server tools, supporting this is identical to the "multiple modules per project" that came and went during WTP 1.0 development. We just need to revive (readd) two methods from 0.7:
* ServerUtil.getModule(IProject) returns the module in a given project. This is ambiguous when there are multiple modules, so a ServerUtil.getModules(IProject) needs to be added.
* The ModuleFactoryDelegate that jst.j2ee implements must be modified to allow (and cache) multiple modules per project.

Tim, I approve this change but with comments. I assume old one will be marked deprecated, but continue to work "as is" (even though sort of "broken") and that the new one will just return an array of length one in the non-multiple case.
Please, also, document what the list might consist of, since "modules" has such a history with us ... I'm guessing one "source" module and potentially other "binary" modules? (I'll have to trust you and Chuck that "module" is the best term to use .. . not leave getModule but add 'getJars'?
Also, please make a note in http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/New_Help_for_Old_Friends and post a short note to wtp-dev list, since, as I understand it, our code will be binary compatible, but to get the corrected behavior, server adapters will have to change their code? (that is, they do not get the fix for free, which is unfortunate, but I see no way to fix that).
Thus, it will also be important the plugins version number is properly incremented, so server adopters who implement this fix (if I understand it right) will need to pre-req a minimum of this fix level.
thanks much.
+1 for 1.5.1 (contingent on resolution of David's questions)

Some clarifications: * These changes are all in wst.server. Although it has no knowledge of jst changes, I've made sure that the existing API will continue to return identical values to that of WTP 1.0 and 1.5.
* The existing API does not need to be deprecated and is still fully functional. Code that continues to use it will work fine if it doesn't want/need to take advantage of the new J2EE feature.
* The getModules() return type is IModule[] and will return an array of length 1 (consistent with existing behaviour) for any project that doesn't contain an EAR with binary projects.
* Server adapters do not need to change and can continue to use the existing API that's been in place since WTP 0.7. The break was jst.j2ee no longer returning any binary module info to server tools, and their separate bug will solve that.
* The only external code that needs to change is "project/module providers" who want to start having multiple modules per project (jst.j2ee) and server tools API users who want to take advantage of the new J2EE structure. People won't use this API because it's there; they'll use it because they want to take advantage of new features/changes in other components.
* I will post to the "New Help" and mailing list, but please keep in mind that this is a secondary reaction to the breakage produced by the change in 1.5. Since it wasn't done by server tools I'm not in a position to document the 1.5 breakage, the scope of the project structure change, or how adopters were broken by the initial change.
* The plugin version number has already been updated for 1.5.1.
Code dropped and released to 1.5.1 and 2.0 builds.
Closing.
This is part of a "mass update" where bugs showing "fixed" between 7/1/2006 and 9/27/2006 are assumed fixed in WTP 1.5.1. feel free to change the target milestone if you know a more accurate setting.

bug.short_desc: PDF Render performance enhancement

long_desc.thetext:
Thanks, Joao. This enhancement improves perforance of PDF report greatly. I replace style.setXXX(String value) with style.setProperty(int index, CSSValue value), which also gets rid of the costly style parsing time.
fixed at build20050801

bug.short_desc: CVS: Cannot Check Out an opened method library

long_desc.thetext:
OS: Windows XP with SP2 Language: English Build: epf-composer-1.0-M4-N20060724-1815-win32 TestCase ID: No
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open a Library which checked into the CVS before in Authoring perspective 2. Switch to CVS Repository Exploring perspective 3. Check out this library from CVS 4. Click OK at confirm delete exist library window -->Problem: Cannot check out library due to locked ".lock" file
Expect result: When Check out an opened library, Library should be closed to release locked file
Remaek: The same problem on Linux platform

In the existing design, the tool won't close the currently opened library because a new library is been checked out from CM. users have to re-open the check-out library.
Also we don't support the checking-out the same library which is currently opened.
Invalid bug, Closed.
